questionText: Each answer lists two Metro Ethernet terms. Which answer(s) lists two terms that both refer to the same Metro Ethernet service?
explanation: There are three different MEF-defined Metro Ethernet services: Ethernet Line Service (E-Line), Ethernet LAN Service (E-LAN), and Ethernet Tree Service (E-Tree). E-Line is used to connect two devices that can exchange Ethernet frames similarly to a point-to-point link. E-LAN acts similarly to a local LAN (full mesh) and allows all devices to directly connect to each other. E-Tree resembles a hub-and-spoke topology and allows a “hub” device to communicate with all “spoke” devices, but the “spokes” are not able to directly communicate without being relayed through the “hub.”

questionText: What is the name of the MetroE concept that defines which user devices can communicate with each other?
explanation: The MetroE Ethernet Virtual Connection (EVC) concept defines which user devices can communicate with each other; for example, an E-Line service defines a single EVC as it only connects together two devices, whereas an E-Tree service could define multiple EVCs depending on the number of “spoke” devices.

questionText: When referencing MPLS VPN Layer 3 configurations, which of the following statements are true?
explanation: When configuring an MPLS VPN the CE and the PE routers can become routing protocol neighbors using a variety of different protocols; but regardless of the protocol used to connect with the CE, Multiprotocol BGP (MP-BGP) is used to transport the customer routes across the provider’s network. The CE routers will not form neighborships with each other in this configuration.

answerChoices.Text: The CE router becomes a routing protocol neighbor with the PE.
The provider uses MP-BGP to transport customer routes.
The provider can use any routing protocol to transport customer routes.
The CE router becomes a routing protocol neighbor with the remote CE.

questionText: Refer to the diagram; which option is the term used to reference the devices indicated with a green arrow?
explanation: MPLS VPNs use the term customer edge (CE) to reference the customer device that directly connects to the provider; the provider router that connects to the CE is referred to as the provider edge (PE) device.

questionText: Refer to the diagram; what is the term that is used to reference the link indicated with the green arrows?
explanation: The term user network interface (UNI) refers to a link between the provider network and a customer (user) network.

questionText: Which MEF-defined Metro Ethernet service acts similarly to a local LAN?
explanation: There are three different MEF-defined Metro Ethernet services: Ethernet Line Service (E-Line), Ethernet LAN Service (E-LAN), and Ethernet Tree Service (E-Tree). E-Line is used to connect two devices that can exchange Ethernet frames similarly to a point-to-point link. E-LAN acts similarly to a local LAN and allows all devices to directly connect to each other. E-Tree resembles a hub-and-spoke topology and allows a “hub” device to communicate with all “spoke” devices, but the “spokes” are not able to directly communicate without being relayed through the “hub.”

questionText: Which MEF-defined Metro Ethernet service has been previously referenced by the name Virtual Private Wire Service?
explanation: There are three different MEF-defined Metro Ethernet services: E-Line (Ethernet Line Service), E-LAN (Ethernet LAN Service), and E-Tree (Ethernet Tree Service). E-Line is used to connect two devices that can exchange Ethernet frames similarly to a point-to-point link; it has also been referred to by the name Virtual Private Wire Service. E-LAN acts similarly to a local LAN and allows all devices to directly connect to each other; it has also been referred to by the name Virtual Private LAN Service. E-Tree resembles a hub-and-spoke topology and allows a “hub” device to communicate with all “spoke” devices, but the “spokes” are not able to directly communicate without being relayed through the “hub.”

questionText: Of the different public cloud WAN options, which can be utilized to rapidly deploy a public cloud?
explanation: The Internet and Internet VPN options can be used to rapidly deploy a public cloud. The other options, Ethernet WAN, MPLS VPN, and Intercloud Exchange, take significantly more time to stand up.

questionText: Which public cloud WAN connection options do not offer the ability to have reliable QoS?
explanation: Any solution that is based on the Internet as a transport will not be able to guarantee quality of service (QoS), because the Internet itself is based on a best-effort model; this means that it doesn’t guarantee that your traffic will have any specific traffic characteristics between your location and any destination. Because of this, both the Internet and Internet VPN public cloud WAN connection methods would not be able to offer reliable QoS.

questionText: Of the different public cloud WAN options, which have quality of service capabilities to ensure end-to-end application requirements?
explanation: Intercloud exchange, Ethernet WAN, and MPLS VPN all have capabilities that provide quality of service. The only options that do not inherently provide any quality of service capabilities are the Internet and Internet VPN. Keep in mind that once your traffic leaves your perimeter into the Internet it is no longer under your control, and you cannot guarantee any QoS requirements.

questionText: An engineer configures a router that formerly had no VRFs to add two VRFs. The configuration also places some interfaces in one VRF and some in another. How many IP routing tables does the router have now?
explanation:
Devices that perform routing - routers and multilayer switches - use virtual routing and forwarding (VRF) instances to create multiple instances of a router within one device. Without VRFs, a router has a single routing table, and the router places all IP routes into one IP routing table. With VRFs, the router creates a routing table for each VRF. Additional configuration can place interfaces into the VRFs so that their connected routes land in the associated per-VRF routing table. The routing protocol configuration can also place routing protocol neighbor relationships into the different VRFs, so routes learned via those neighbors again land in the correct per-VRF routing table.

A router without VRFs has a single IP routing table. Once configured to use VRFs, the router has the original IP routing table (the global routing table) plus one IP routing table per VRF. Interfaces and routing protocol neighbors not placed into a VRF feed their routes into the global routing table.

In this question, with two VRFs, the router has three IP routing tables: one per VRF plus the global routing table.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. After some troubleshooting, you notice that hosts on the 192.168.2.0/24 network cannot connect to any network resources but are able to ping their gateway. According to the configuration, what is the issue?
explanation:
In the OSPF configuration, no network commands match the router's interface in network 192.168.2.0/24 is missing. As a result, OSPF is not enabled on the interface and does not advertise about network 192.168.2.0/24.

	For the incorrect answers:

	
		The router-id command can list any IP address value, whether it exists as an interface IP address on the local router, some other router, or not at all.
	
		For the the router ospf 10 command, the 10 refers to the OSPF Process ID, not an area. Any value between 1 and 65535 is allowed.
	
		The answer about multiple network commands with area 0 parameters is not correct. Those commands assign the matched interfaces to area 0, and as many network commands as necessary can be used to assign different interfaces to area 0.

answerChoices.Text: The list of network commands does not match interface Fa0/1.
The router-id command should not use a number equal to an interface's IP address.
The configuration should list only one network command with area 0 paremeters.
The router ospf 10 command incorrectly refers to area 10 instead of area 0.

questionText: OSPF uses what algorithm to calculate the best route to reach each subnet?
explanation:
OSPF uses the Dijsktra SPF algorithm to process the contents of the OSPF Link State Database (LSDB) to produce the best route from a router to each subnet. Other routing protocols use these algorithms:

	
		EIGRP: DUAL
	
		BGP: Path Vector
	
		RIP: Distance Vector

questionText: Which command would you enter to add an IP address on a router interface?
explanation: The command to add an IP address on a router interface is ip address 172.16.10.1 255.255.255.0.

questionText: The exhibit shows the output of the show ip interface brief command on router R1. All the interfaces listed in the exhibit should work under normal conditions and have worked in the past. Which of the following is the most likely condition that would cause the output shown in the exhibit?
explanation: Fa0/1 is in an "up/down" state, which generally refers to Layer 2 problems. For the answer that suggests the adjacent switch interface shut down, if that were the case, R1 would not see any electrical signals on the cable, so R1 would instead place the interface in a "down/down" state, implying a physical layer problem. S0/0/0 has a shutdown command configured, so there is no way to know whether the actual link has any Layer 1, Layer 2, or Layer 3 problems. S0/0/1 does not have an IP address assigned, but the lack of an IP address would not cause the "down/down" status, so some other problem (probably related to Layer 1) exists. For S0/1/0, which is in an "up/down" state, the state implies a Layer 2 issue, so the mismatched configuration of Layer 2 protocols would be one reason for the problem.

answerChoices.Text: The switch port connected to R1's Fa0/1 interface has been shut down on the switch.
The serial link connected to S0/0/0 is having problems inside the  telco's network, with the telco not currently supplying a clock signal.
The router on the other end of R1's S0/1/0 interface has been configured to use PPP, but R1 still defaults to using HDLC.
R1's S0/0/1 does not have any problems other than the fact that no IP address has yet been assigned.

questionText: Of the Cisco IOS commands that are typically used to view interface IP addressing information, which one shows only the address but not the mask information configured for an interface?
explanation: A number of different commands can be used to view IP addressing configuration information about the interfaces on a router. Some of them include show ip interface, show ip interface brief, show interfaces, show protocols, and show running-config. One of the most commonly used is the show ip interface brief command because it gives a nice abridged output of the configured IP addresses along with the status of each of the router’s interfaces; however, this command does not include any information about the configured subnet mask for the interfaces.

questionText: Which of the following can be used to place a valid route into the routing table of a Cisco IOS router?
explanation:
Routes can be added to the routing table of an IOS router by configuring an IP address on an up/up interface, adding static routes or by dynamically learning routes through a routing protocol such as OSPF.

	Name-to-IP mapping, such as local or DNS services, doesn’t add routes to the routing table. Using wildcard masks, which apply to ACLs and some network statements, on their own, doesn’t specifically add routes to a router’s routing table.

answerChoices.Text: Add an IP address to an up/up interface
Apply the use of wildcard masks
Use OSPF with more than one router

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. What is the subnet mask of the LAN directly connected to R1?
explanation: Every working directly connected router interface has two routing table entries. One is a local (host) route for the one IP address configured on the interface, and the other is a network route for the directly connected link. In this case, the locally connected LAN includes the subnet 10.10.10.0/24, which can also be written as 10.10.10.0 255.255.255.0.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit and diagram. Which static route statement could you add to the central router to ensure that a default route  always exists in the routing table regardless of the interface state?
explanation: The correct way to write a static default route is ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 {next-hop-ip | next-hop-interface}. The permanent keyword when used with the ip route command will allow a static route to be added to the routing table regardless of the state of the next-hop IP or interface. The incorrect answers with the summary keyword are invalid commands. The incorrect answer that has the permanent keyword, but with subnet and mask of 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255, incorrectly defines the default route.

questionText: After adding the command ip route 30.30.30.0 255.255.255.0 10.10.10.2 to router R1's configuration, the show ip route command on R1 does not list a static route for subnet 30.30.30.0. Which answer(s) list a reason that would cause the route to not appear?
explanation:
There are a few main reasons why a router would not add a route to the routing table once configured and added to the configuration file. Some of these reasons include:

- The ip route command references an outgoing interface, and that interface is down

- The ip route command references a next-hop router address and there is no route to that next-hop address

- There is another route with the same prefix/mask, but with a lower administrative distance

The two correct answers point back to the same root cause, because both would mean that the local router would not have a route to reach the next-hop address as configured in the ip route command.

As for the incorrect answers, both answers would cause the command to be rejected when configured so that it was not even added to the configuration file.

answerChoices.Text: The configured destination is a subnet broadcast address.
The router interface that leads towards the configured next-hop router is down.
The router has no route to the next-hop IP address.

questionText:
All routers and interfaces in the figure work. The text below shows the only current IP route for subnet 172.16.30.192/26 in router R1. At that point, an engineer configures the command ip route 172.16.30.192 255.255.255.192 172.16.13.3 120 on router R1. Which answer describes how router R1 processes the command?


R1# show ip route
! Lines omitted for brevity
      172.16.0.0/16 is variably subnetted, 4 subnets, 2 masks
O        172.16.30.192/26 [110/3] via 172.16.12.2, 00:04:56, GigabitEthernet0/0/1
explanation:
This question revolves around the administrative distance of the existing route and the route defined in the ip route command as a classic example of a floating static route. Per the output in the exhibit, the existing route has an administrative distance of 110. The route also has a code that means it is an OSPF interarea route, and OSPF uses a default administrative distance of 110. So the route appears to have been learned by OSPF. The ip route command in the question ends with 120, which is the administrative distance applied to the route in the command.

Additionally, note that the existing route defines a route to subnet 172.16.30.192, mask /26. The /26 mask is equivalent to mask 255.255.255.192, the mask used in the ip route command. So both the existing route and the route in the ip route command refer to the same subnet.

IOS accepts the configuration command, adding it to the running-config file, because there are no syntax or value errors in the command. Because the command uses a higher administrative distance, IOS does not add a route to the routing table. If the router ever loses the OSPF route to that subnet, IOS would add a route based on this configured static route.

answerChoices.Text: It adds the command to the running-config file but does not add a route to the routing table.
It rejects the command with an error message
It adds the command to the running-config file and replaces the route shown in the exhibit.
It adds the command to the running-config file and adds the route to the routing table, retaining the route shown in the exhibit.

questionText:
Refer to the diagram. Which static route statements on R1 would be configured to ensure that:
	- all normal device traffic going to the 30.30.30.0 network would be routed via the primary path, and
	- all traffic going to ServerA would be routed via the high-priority path?
explanation:
Two different static route statements are needed to meet the requirements: one routes all normal traffic, and the other is specific to the traffic destined for ServerA. The first correct statement is ip route 30.30.30.0 255.255.255.0 20.20.20.2. The 255.255.255.0 mask matches all traffic destined for addresses that begin with exactly 30.30.30, while the fourth octet can be any valid number. The second correct statement is a host route; it is ip route 30.30.30.100 255.255.255.255 10.10.10.2. The 255.255.255.255 mask matches all traffic destined for only the 30.30.30.100 address.

	The two incorrect statements both use invalid masks.
comments:
11/22 - ok as-is, "the statement refers to the “ip route 30.30.30.0 255.255.255.0…” command (answer A in the image). It refers to the fact that the subnet ID and subnet mask in the command (yes, the 255.255.255.0 in the command is a subnet mask, not a wildcard mask), when you think about the range of addresses in the subnet, means “all addresses that begin 30.30.30”. So that phrase means that the static route, once in the IP routing table, matches all packets whose destination addresses begin 30.30.30."

11/10 - query to Au

questionText: When using static routes, you type in ip route 10.1.1.0 255.255.255.0, and two options are available to specify the next hop as the next parameters in the command. Select the two valid choices.
explanation: When using the ip route command, you can specify an IP address as the next hop, or an interface out which to send the packet.
comments: 6/17 - ok as-is , 6/1 - query to Au, CD-I2-4-55-008-1

questionText: Refer to the diagram. An engineer is attempting to change the routing for the traffic to the 30.30.30.0/24 network via a static route. IOS accepts the ip route command; however, the new static route is not displayed in the IP routing table. What could cause this issue?
explanation: There are a few main reasons why a static route that was entered would not be displayed in the routing table even though it was entered and accepted. Some of these reasons include that the outgoing interface is down or that there is no route for the next-hop IP address. Other reasons include that there could be a more specific route available that overrides the entered route or that the administrative distance of another route is lower and has priority.
comments: 9/22 - correct as-is, 9/12 - query to Au, also fixed typo in Explanation.

answerChoices.Text: There is an overriding competing route.
There is no route to the next-hop IP address.

questionText: The figure shows the IP address and mask of several router interfaces. All interfaces are up and working. An engineer configures the command ip route 172.16.2.160 255.255.255.192 172.16.12.2 command on router R1 to create a route to the subnet on the right side of router R2. Which answer best describes the result?
explanation:
To accept the command into the configuration, it must have correct syntax. Also, the two numeric parameters must pass a test in which the first number is a subnet ID when using the configured mask, rather than being an address or a subnet broadcast address. IOS would reject the command if the first numeric value was not a subnet ID. In this case, the command fails the value test, confirming the one correct answer. The math:


	Configured “subnet” 172.16.2.160
	Configured mask 255.255.255.192 (correct)
	Subnetting math reveals: Subnet ID 172.16.2.128, subnet broadcast address 172.16.2.191, range of valid addresses 172.16.2.129 – 190.


As a result, the router would reject the configuration command and not add it to the configuration file.

The key to the rest of the answers can be easily ruled out because IOS will not attempt to add a route if it already rejected the ip route command.

answerChoices.Text: R1 rejects the ip route command due to syntax or value errors.
R1 accepts the ip route command into the configuration but does not add the route to the routing table.
R1 accepts the command and adds the route to the routing table, but it does not forward packets to the subnet to the right of router R2.
R1 accepts the command and adds the route to the routing table, and it forwards packets to the subnet to the right of router R2.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit and the figure. A branch office is going to be using an Ethernet WAN link as the primary WAN link, with a serial point-to-point link as a backup. The design uses OSPF over the Ethernet WAN link. What command enables you to configure a floating static route on the branch router to the 200.200.200.0/24 network should the primary link fail?
explanation:
A floating static route is a method that is used to add a static route to the routing table should an existing better route disappear. This usually happens when the main routing protocol that is used is cut off from a spoke/branch. When the device sees that the routing protocol route has been removed from the routing table, it inserts the static route (thus the floating). In this case, the 200.200.200.0/24 network exists off of the central router. To back it up, a route must be added that points the routing for this prefix through the central backup router. (A similar action is done at the central location, as well, to ensure that a return route exists).

	Note that the administrative distance of the floating static route in this case needed to be a higher number than 110, the default administrative distance used by OSPF. Of the three incorrect answers, Two give an administrative distance less than 110, so that the static route would be in the routing table even when OSPF was learning a route for the same subnet. Also, two of the incorrect answers point to the wrong next-hop router (50.50.50.1 and 100.100.100.2), so they would not be used.
comments:
8/4 - query to Au

2/4 - "the next-hop addresses are not in the figure. They are found in the exhibit, which lists relevant router configuration for this question."  2/2 - query to Au, 12/17 - ok as-is, " think about the perspective from the branch router. The IP routes on a router list the neighboring router’s IP address, specifically the IP address on the link that connects the two routers. In this case:

A route w/ “Central Site” as the next hop will list Central Site’s Fa0/1 IP address of 50.50.50.1.
A route w/ “Central Site Backup” as the next hop will list Central Site Backup’s S1/0 IP address of 150.150.150.1.

So, to answer your specific question, 100.100.100.2 is incorrect as it is the Central Site Backup  router’s IP address on its F0/0 interface, an interface that is not connected a link w/ the Branch router.
As for why 150.150.150.1 is correct, that’s an address on a neighboring router on a link connected to the Branch router."  , 12/14 - query to Au

questionText: The figure shows all subnets used in a small lab network. An engineer configures the command ip route 10.4.64.0 255.255.254.0 10.4.12.2 command on router R1, and the router adds the command to its running-config file. However, a static route does not appear in router R1’s routing table. Which answers give a reason why R1 would not add the static route to the table?
explanation:
For the correct answer, only a few reasons exist that result in the router accepting the command into the configuration while also not adding a route to the routing table. To accept the command into the configuration, it must have correct syntax. Also, the two numeric parameters must pass a test in which the first number is a subnet ID when using the configured mask, rather than being an address or a subnet broadcast address. IOS would reject the command if the first numeric value was not a subnet ID.

Once in the configuration, IOS would not add the route to the routing table if:


	A better route (with a lower administrative distance) already exists in the routing table
	The static route’s next-hop address (if configured) is not reachable by the router.
	The static route’s outgoing interface (if configured) is not in an up/up state.


Only one of those reasons appears in the answers and is the correct answer in this case. R1 would not have a connected route matching next-hop address 10.4.12.2 if the link between the routers were down, for instance.

For the incorrect answer that mentions the lack of an administrative distance parameter, that parameter is optional, defaulting to 1, and the command is fine without that parameter.

For the answer claiming that the first numeric parameter is not a subnet ID, it is incorrect. You can do the math on the values in the ip route command to confirm that fact. However, the question tells you the router accepted the command and added it to the configuration, which confirms that the router thinks the values are acceptable.

Finally, one answer claims that the subnet listed by the command is not the subnet connected to router R2. That claim is not true; it is the subnet listed off R2 in the figure. However, even if the ip route command referred to a non-existent subnet, it would still add the route to the routing table. Router R1 has no way of knowing if the subnet exists or not.

answerChoices.Text: R1’s routing table has no route that matches address 10.4.12.2.
The ip route command does not list an administrative distance parameter.
The ip route command’s first numeric value lists an address rather than a subnet ID.
The subnet listed in the ip route command is not the same subnet shown off router R2 in the figure.

questionText: The router in the figure provides routing services for all subnets residing on the VLANs in the figure. The switch performs layer 2 switching services only. On the router, which Cisco IOS command would be configured on R1’s Gi0/0.200 interface so that it handles all traffic marked for VLAN 200?
explanation: The encapsulation dot1q vlan command is used to assign a specific router subinterface to a trunk VLAN. In this case the encapsulation dot1q 200 command would allow R1’s Gi0/0.200 to handle all traffic marked with VLAN 200.

answerChoices.Text: Both VLAN interfaces remain in an up/up state.
Interface VLAN 11 fails to an up/down state, while interface VLAN 12 remains up/up.
Interface VLAN 12 fails to an up/down state, while interface VLAN 11 remains up/up.

questionText: The router in the figure provides routing services for all subnets residing on the VLANs in the figure. The switch performs layer 2 switching services only. On the router, which Cisco IOS command would be configured on R1’s Gi0/0.300 interface so that it handles all non-marked traffic from VLAN 300?
explanation: The encapsulation dot1q vlan command is used to assign a specific router subinterface to a trunk VLAN. The addition of the native parameter at the end of the command assigns all non-marked traffic to that interface; this VLAN is referred to as the native VLAN. In this scenario, R1’s Gi0/0.300 interface is configured with VLAN 300 and handles all non-marked traffic when configured with the encapsulation dot1q 300 native command.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command is used on a router’s Ethernet subinterface to associate it with VLAN 100?
explanation: When Router-on-a-Stick (ROAS) is configured on a router, the encapsulation command is used on a router’s Ethernet subinterface to associate it with a specific VLAN. The addition of the native keyword at the end will treat the specific VLAN as native for the interface and all the subinterfaces; this means that all frames that are received without an IEEE 802.1q tag will be routed to this interface (or subinterface). In this case, to associate a subinterface with the VLAN 100, the encapsulation dot1q 100 command would be used while in subinterface configuration mode.

questionText: In the figure, the switch acts as a layer 2 switch only. The router provides routing for all LAN-based subnets using ROAS. Which command must be configured on SW1’s Gi0/0 interface to ensure proper functionality?
explanation: When configuring router-on-a-stick (ROAS), the switch side of the connection to the router must be manually configured to be a trunk because routers don’t support dynamic trunking negotiation; this is done by using the switchport mode trunk command on the appropriate interface.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. Which answer gives the reason why the SVI in the exhibit has a down/down state?
explanation:
First, connect the term SVI to the term "VLAN interface" and look for any VLAN interfaces. The show ip interface brief command lists interface VLAN100 at the end of the output. VLAN100 is a Switched Virtual Interface, or SVI - another name for a VLAN interface. Per that output, SVI (VLAN interface 100) is in a down/down state.

	Several issues can cause a switch to list a VLAN interface in a down/down state. Or stated positively, the following must be true for an SVI to be in an up/up state:

	
		The corresponding VLAN must exist on the switch
	
		The corresponding VLAN (VLAN 100 in this case) must be active (that is, not shutdown)
	
		At least one access interface must be configured to be in the corresponding VLAN, OR... a operational trunk interface exists and the VLAN is included in the trunk's allowed list
	
		The SVI (the VLAN interface) must be enabled, that is, not shutdown


	If any of the first three conditions are not true, the SVI lands in a down/down state. If the SVI is shutdown, the switch places the SCI into an administratively down state. 

	For this scenario, the exhibit shows that VLAN 100, per the show vlan brief command, is in an act/lshut state, meaning that the VLAN (not the VLAN interface, but the VLAN) has been shutdown. As a result, the switch places the matching VLAN interface into a down/down state.

answerChoices.Text: The SVI is down because the VLAN is shut down.
The SVI is down because it is not enabled with STP.
The SVI is down because the VLAN doesn’t exist.
The SVI is down because there is no enabled interface configured into the VLAN.
The SVI is down because it is shut down.

questionText: Which answer shows the correct configuration for 802.1Q encapsulation on a router subinterface for VLAN 2?

In the figure, PC1 is in VLAN 1, PC6 is in VLAN 5, and R1 is using 802.1Q trunking and the default native VLAN. R1 has an IP address associated with both VLAN 1 and VLAN 5, as shown.  When you consider only the traffic that flows in both directions between PC1 and PC6 and no other traffic in the network, which of the following is true?
explanation: The interfaces that are connected to PC1 and PC6 do not use trunking, so a VLAN tag would never be in the normal Ethernet header. With 802.1Q, VLAN 1 is the native VLAN by default; therefore, no VLAN tag is used. The only frames that have VLAN tags in this case are those in VLAN 5, as they pass between R1 and the switch.

answerChoices.Text: Frames that SW1 forwards out fa0/1 to PC1 have a VLAN 1 tag in front of the normal Ethernet header.
Frames that SW1 forwards out fa0/6 to PC6 have a VLAN 5 tag in front of the normal Ethernet header.
After SW1 receives a frame from PC1, SW1 forwards the frame out fa0/22  to R1. This forwarded frame has a VLAN 1 tag in the Ethernet header as  it exits SW1’s fa0/22 interface.
After SW1 receives a frame from PC6, SW1  forwards the frame out fa0/22 to R1. This forwarded frame has a VLAN 5  tag in the Ethernet header as it exits SW1’s fa0/22 interface

questionText:
VLAN interfaces 11 and 12 on switch SW1 rest in an up/up state. Refer to the command output in the exhibit. An engineer connects to the switch and issues two sets of new configuration commands. First, they issue shutdown command in interface G1/0/2 configuration mode. Next, they issue the shutdown command in VLAN 12 configuration mode. Both VLAN interfaces use the default autostate setting. Which answer best describes the new state of the two VLAN interfaces?


SW1# show interfaces status
Port      Name           Status       Vlan       Duplex  Speed Type 
Gi1/0/1                  connected    11         a-full  a-100 10/100/1000BaseTX
Gi1/0/2                  connected    11           auto   auto 10/100/1000BaseTX
Gi1/0/3                  connected    12         a-full  a-100 10/100/1000BaseTX
Gi1/0/4                  connected    12         a-full  a-100 10/100/1000BaseTX
explanation:
First, the terminology can get in the way when discussing VLANs and VLAN interfaces. A VLAN includes all devices in the same broadcast domain. The configuration defines the VLAN with the vlan vlan-id global command. Access ports have an assigned access VLAN, while trunk ports support many VLANs. The term VLAN interface refers to a switch's layer 3 interface that connects to the VLAN, on which the switch configuration can include an IP address. The configuration creates such an interface with the interface vlan vlan-id global command.

The question asks about the state of two VLAN interfaces, with the question text ending by noting that both VLAN interfaces use the autostate setting (the default.) As a result, the interfaces require several states to be good for the VLAN interface to be up/up, including:


	At least one working physical interface in that VLAN, including access VLANs and trunks that include the VLAN in the allowed VLAN list.
	The VLAN (not the VLAN interface, but the VLAN) must be defined and active (that is, not shutdown).
	The VLAN interface must not be shutdown.


The question tells us that both VLAN interfaces are initially in an up/up state, so at that point, all these criteria must be true. For the VLAN 11 interface, the new configuration disables one physical link (G1/0/2), but interface G1/0/1, also in VLAN 11 per the exhibit, remains active. So that action does not cause interface VLAN 11 to fail.

The second new configuration item disables VLAN 12 with the shutdown command. As a result, IOS disables the associated VLAN 12 interface. So, the correct answer notes that interface VLAN 11 remains up, but that interface VLAN 12 fails.

answerChoices.Text: Both VLAN interfaces remain in an up/up state.
Interface VLAN 11 fails to an up/down state, while interface VLAN 12 remains up/up.
Interface VLAN 12 fails to an up/down state, while interface VLAN 11 remains up/up.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command would be used on a switched interface to enable it to become a routed interface?
explanation: On some switches it is possible to convert switched interfaces into routed interfaces by using the no switchport command. Routed ports are commonly used when a switch is only connected to a subnet via a single interface, where a switched virtual interface (SVI) is not required.

questionText: A Cisco switch configures several ports into each VLAN. It also provides IP routing services for the subnets on each VLAN. Which answers list a configuration step for the switch to support routing using only SVIs?
explanation:
First, and not listed as an answer, the switch must support IP routing in its forwarding ASIC. Older Cisco switches require a command and a reload to enable that feature, while newer Cisco models do not.

Once completed, the configuration must:


	enable IPv4 routing (the ip routing command)
	Create the associated VLANs (with the vlan id commands)
	Create the related SVIs (the VLAN interfaces) (with the interface VLAN id commands)
	Enable IPv4 on each SVI (with the ip address address mask interface subcommands)


Note that the one incorrect answer lists a configuration step when using routed interfaces rather than when using SVIs. The correct answers come from the above list.

answerChoices.Text: The switch is enabled for IP routing.
Each routed physical interface must be configured with an IP address.
Each VLAN interface must be configured with an IP address.
The VLAN associated with the VLAN interface must be configured and active.

questionText: When you are configuring routed ports on a Layer 3 switch, what do the physical interfaces act as?
explanation: You can configure interfaces on a Layer 3 switch as a routed port (Layer 3) as opposed to a switchport (Layer 2). SVI does not change the behavior of a physical port on a switch.

questionText: Router R1 has two routed interfaces: G0/0/0 and G0/0/1, connected to Ethernet WAN links. R1 also has eight switched interfaces, numbered G0/1/0 – G0/1/7, each connected to a PC. Router R1 acts as the default router for all PCs. In which configuration mode would you expect to see configuration for the IP address R1 uses as the default router for those PCs?
explanation:
When using a router with LAN switch ports, the router configuration mimics the configuration in a layer 3 switch. That configuration includes layer 2 settings on the physical interfaces, for instance, setting a VLAN ID with the switchport access vlan vlan-id interface subcommand. To configure IP settings, you configure a VLAN interface for each VLAN used on those embedded switch ports. 

To create the VLAN interface, use the interface vlan vlan-id command. That command moves the CLI into VLAN interface config mode, where you can configure the ip address command to configure the router's IP address on that interface. The PCs in that VLAN will use that address as their default router setting.

The above facts detail why the correct answer is correct. For the incorrect answers:


	Interfaces G0/0/0 and G0/0/1 will have ip address commands configured, but those will not define the IP address of the default router used by the PCs.  
	If in configuration mode for any of the switched ports (G0/1/0 – G0/1/7), IOS would reject the ip address command because the port is incapable of layer 3 features.
	The answer that mentions subinterfaces implies a router-on-a-stick (ROAS) configuration due to its use of subinterfaces. Routers use ROAS configuration on a routed Ethernet interface, which is not the case described in the question.

answerChoices.Text: Interface configuration mode for interfaces G0/0/0 – G0/0/1.
Interface configuration mode for interfaces G0/1/0 – G0/1/7.
Interface configuration mode for one or more subinterfaces of physical interfaces G0/1/0 – G0/1/7.
Interface configuration mode for one or more VLAN interfaces.

questionText: Which two steps must you perform to enable router-on-a-stick on a router subinterface?

answerChoices.Text: Configure an IP route to the VLAN.
Configure IEEE 802.1q encapsulation for the VLAN.
Configure the subinterface with an IP address.

questionText: A LAN switch connects to a Cisco router. The LAN switch creates several VLANs and works as a layer 2 switch, while the router provides routing for all subnets on the VLANs using a ROAS configuration. Which answers list a valid command for the switch which confirms that the switch port connected to the router currently operates as a trunk?

The diagram shows the correct details for a new ROAS configuration on router R1. Another co-worker, tasked with creating the configuration, asks you to review their proposed config (see exhibit.) Which options are true of the potential configuration of R1?
explanation:
There are a few problems that exist in this potential configuration.

First, the encapsulation dot1q command is not allowed under the physical interface, but it is shown in the configuration. That command is used only under ROAS subinterfaces.

Second, the native VLAN should be configured to be processed by one special subinterface or by the physical interface, but not both. To process the native VLAN with the physical interface, you would simply give the physical interface an IP address, as is shown here. However, the encapsulation dot1q 30 native subcommnand tells the router to process the native VLAN's traffic on the matching subinterface. A correct configuration should do one or the other, but not both.

Finally, the VLAN assignment commands (encapsulation dot1q) that are configured on subinterfaces Gi0/0.200 and Gi0/0.300 are reversed; this would cause traffic to be handled by the wrong subinterfaces in comparison to the figure. It is also important to note that the subinterface numbers that are used do not affect VLAN assignments; they are separate. While it is considered best practice to use numbers that are easy to reference, it is not required.
comments:
5/31 - ok as-is, "In this case, the question was set up with two correct answers, and you believe there to be three. After comparing a screen shot of what you saw, it looks like you believe this answer to also be correct:

"The mismatch of VLAN IDs and subinterface numbers will prevent the trunk from working."

As it turns out, that answer is incorrect. In a router ROAS configured, the sub interface IDs and VLAN numbers do not need to match. Often, engineers choose the same numbers, just to make it easier to keep track, but it is not a requirement that they match. So, the question has the only two correct answers noted."
5/13 - query to Au, , 5/2, 4/29 - ok as-is

answerChoices.Text: It will work fine, as expected.
The mismatch of VLAN IDs and subinterface numbers will prevent the trunk from working.
The interfaces handling the VLAN 20 and 40 traffic have their assignment commands reversed.
The interfaces handling the VLAN 30 and 40 traffic have their assignment commands reversed.
The physical interface has a command that is invalid.
The VLAN assignment commands are all using the wrong syntax.

questionText: The exhibit lists four configuration options. Which option correctly configures ROAS for four different VLANS (100, 200, 300, and 400), while using the physical interface to handle native VLAN traffic?
explanation: The encapsulation dot1q vlan command is used to assign a specific router subinterface to a trunk VLAN. The addition of the native parameter at the end of the command assigns all non-marked traffic to that interface; this VLAN is referred to as the native VLAN. In this scenario the router needs to be configured into four different VLANs plus the native default VLAN (1); when using the physical interface to handle the native VLAN traffic, no additional configuration is required. Each of the subinterfaces would be configured with the encapsulation dot1q vlan command for the different VLANs.

questionText: Examine the exhibit, which shows output taken from a router. Which answers describe correct conclusions about the two interfaces in the exhibit supported by the output? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
Over their long history, most router interfaces behaved like router interfaces. However, eventually, Cisco began offering router hardware that integrated router and switch features. Over time, Cisco added small sets of LAN switch ports for some router models. In Cisco's implementation of these interfaces, Cisco refers to interfaces that behave like traditional router interfaces as routed interfaces or routed ports, and the interfaces that act like LAN-switched ports are called switched interfaces or switched ports.

Identifying the routed and switched ports can be challenging. On Cisco routers, the interface cannot change from one to the other once you order and receive the router. Instead, you can order Cisco routers, and depending on the model, they may have only routed interfaces, or they may also include some switched interfaces. 

You can identify the type of port from the configuration: routed ports support the ip address subcommand (while switch ports do not, and switched ports support only layer 2 configuration commands, like the switchport access vlan command, while routed ports do not. Based on these facts, the ip address command under interface G0/0/0 confirms the interface is a routed port, and the presence of the switchport access vlan command under interface G0/1/4 confirms it is a switched port.

As a result, When using a router with LAN switch ports, the router configuration mimics the configuration in a layer 3 switch. That configuration includes layer 2 settings on the physical interfaces, for instance, setting a VLAN ID with the switchport access vlan vlan-id interface subcommand. To configure IP settings, you configure a VLAN interface for each VLAN used on those embedded switch ports. 

To create the VLAN interface, use the interface vlan vlan-id command. That command moves the CLI into VLAN interface config mode, where you can configure the ip address command to configure the router's IP address on that interface. The PCs in that VLAN will use that address as their default router setting.

answerChoices.Text: Of the two interfaces, only G0/0/0 is a routed interface.
Of the two interfaces, only G0/1/4 is a routed interface.
Of the two interfaces, only G0/0/0 is a switched interface.
Of the two interfaces, only G0/1/4 is a switched interface.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command (not Cisco IOS XE) displays the VLANs configured for a ROAS configuration?
explanation:
The show vlans command (note the plural vlans) displays the detail of the different VLANs configured for ROAS along with the interface or subinterface handling native traffic, plus some brief packet statistics.

The show vlan command (note the singular vlan) does not exist as a complete command in IOS in Cisco routers. It is a too-short abbreviation for the commands show vlans and show vlan-switch, with the latter command listing VLAN configuration on a router that has integrated LAN switch ports.

The command show vlan brief works in IOS on LAN switches as well as on IOS XE on routers, displaying VLAN configuration. On routers, the command displays useful information only if the router includes LAN switch ports.

questionText: Which switch Cisco IOS command moves the user from global config mode to the correct mode to configure a management IP address that exists in VLAN 300?
explanation: The interface vlan number command in configuration mode moves the user to VLAN interface configuration mode. Layer 2 switches can have a single active SVI at a time, but the SVI can be the SVI for any VLAN. In this case, the correct command for the interface connected internally to VLAN 300 is of course the interface vlan 300 command. From within this mode, an engineer can configure the interface with common commands like ip address.

questionText: What is the purpose of configuring multiple SVI interfaces on a layer 3 switch?

answerChoices.Text: To provide Layer 2 connectivity to other switches
To provide a reachable IP address for remote administration of the switch
To support routing between the subnets residing on local VLANs

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command is used on a router’s Ethernet subinterface to associate it with VLAN 200 and make it the interface that handles untagged frames?
explanation: When Router-on-a-Stick (ROAS) is configured on a router, the encapsulation command is used on a router’s Ethernet subinterface to associate it with a specific VLAN. The addition of the native keyword at the end will treat the specific VLAN as native for the interface and all the subinterfaces. This means that all frames that are received without an IEEE 802.1q tag will be routed to this interface (or subinterface). In this case, to associate a subinterface with the VLAN 200 and enable it to handle untagged frames, use the encapsulation dot1q 200 native command, which would be used while in subinterface configuration mode. It is important to be aware that by configuring this interface as native, all untagged frames that are received will be considered and processed as VLAN 200 traffic.

questionText: The diagram shows a design that uses a four-link layer 3 EtherChannel. Which answers list interface subcommands with appropriate settings for the physical interfaces on switch SW1 that are part of this EtherChannel?
explanation:
There are a few commands that are required to configure a Layer 3 EtherChannel. For the physical interfaces, the channel-group command must be configured. The interface also needs the no switchport command to enable the port as a routed port. The physical port does not need an IP address, so configuring the no ip address command is useful for clarity when others view the configuration. The following commands show a sample configuration for SW1.


interface range GigabitEthernet0/1-4
 no switchport
 no ip address
 channel-group 1 mode on
!
interface Port-channel1
 no switchport
 ip address 10.10.10.1 255.255.255.0

questionText: Which OSPF message type is used to actually send the LSAs between neighbors?
explanation: The OSPF Link-State Update (LSU) message type is used to send requested LSAs between neighbors; the Link-State Request (LSR) message type is used to request those LSAs that are specific missing from a router’s link-state database (LSDB). The OSPF Database Description (DD) message type is used to exchange a list of known LSAs between neighbors; it is from this list that a router learns which LSAs it does not know.

questionText: Which answers correctly describe the function and use of OSPF database description (DD) messages?
explanation:
Several OSPF message types exist, including:

	Hello: Used by a router to announce itself to neighbors, discover other neighbors, and to decide if two routers have matching settings so they can become neighbors. 
	Link-State Update (LSU): Used by a router to send LSAs to a neighbor. The LSAs each contain the detailed data about the LSA.
	Link-State Database Descriptor (DD): Used by a router after becoming a neighbor, but before sending LSUs, to send a summary list of LSAs to a neighbor. The routers use the lists in the DD message as part of the process of deciding which LSAs it should exchange with LSU packets.
	Three answers describe the function of the DD message, with the one describing how DD messages list the known LSAs being the correct answer.

	Two answers mention the timing of the use of DD packets. These packets occur after routers become neighbors, but before (and in preparation for) sending LSU packets.
comments: 9/13 - adj typo in Explanation, 6/28 - query to au

answerChoices.Text: To exchange lists identifying known LSAs.
To exchange detailed contents of known LSAs.
To exchange counts of known LSAs by type.
Used after forming a neighbor relationship but before any Link State Update (LSU) messages.
Used after forming any neighbor relationships and after any Link State Update (LSU) messages.

questionText: What is the default reference bandwidth for the OSPF algorithm for most Cisco IOS routers?
explanation: The reference bandwidth is a value in Mbps that you can set yourself. However, the default reference bandwidth is 100Mbps on Cisco IOS routers.

questionText: Which state have two OSPF routers reached when they have established a neighbor relationship and have completed the exchange of all available link-state advertisements?
explanation:
When two OSPF routers have established a neighbor relationship and decide to exchange the contents of their LSDBs, they move through three states:

	EXSTART: The initial exchange of summary information about the LSDB using Database Description (DD) messages

	LOADING: The state during the exchange of the LSAs using Link State Update (LSU) messages

	FULL: The state reached after the process has completed.

	The question asks for the state at the end of the process, making "FULL" the correct answer.

questionText: Which option describes the way that metrics work with OSPF?
explanation:
OSPF calculates its metric (cost) by utilizing the sum of all interface costs settings for all links in a destination subnet.

	As for the wrong answers:

	- One incorrect answer mentions a route’s slowest link speed and the cumulative delay associated with each interface on the way to the destination subnet. OSPF does not use this logic, although EIGRP does.

	- One incorrect answer mentions the number of routers between a router and the destination subnet. OSPF does not use router hop count, but RIP does.

	- One incorrect answer mentions the sum of interface costs, but also mentions the cost in a received Hello. This answer describes how STP cost calculations work.

answerChoices.Text: The number of routers between a router and the destination subnet
Calculation based on a route’s slowest link speed and the cumulative delay associated with each interface on the way to the destination subnet
The sum of all outgoing interface cost settings for all links in the route to a destination subnet
The sum of the cost of the route's outgoing interface plus the cost listed in the received Hello message

questionText: Two internal OSPF routers connect to the same LAN-based subnet, with router R1 acting as DR and router R2 as BDR. What LSA(s) will R1 create and flood that R2 does not?
explanation:
Every router creates a Type 1 LSA for itself, describing that router and its interfaces.

	A difference does exist with Type 2 LSAs. Type 2 LSAs are network LSAs, created by the designated router in the subnet, which describe the subnet to which multiple routers connect. R1 will create and flood a Type 2 LSA for the subnet, but R2, as BDR, will not.

	The two routers are internal routers, that is, they have interfaces in one area only, and are not area border routers. Type 3 LSAs are summary LSAs, created by the ABR (Area Border Router), describing to one area a subnet that exists in a different area. So neither R1 nor R2 will create any Type 3 LSAs.
comments: 4/8 - query to Au. This question was originally set up as a multiple select, but only one correct answer is provided

answerChoices.Text: There is no difference in the type of LSAs each router creates and floods.

questionText: Review the topology diagram. All the Ethernet links have been manually assigned an OSPF cost of 4.  Each end of the serial link that connects R3 and R4 has been set to an OSPF cost of 15. The entire private network has been configured as a single OSPF area.  What is the cost from R1’s routing table to reach the network 10.45.0.0/24?
explanation:
OSPF considers the outgoing interface costs in the path to a given router. From R1, it is R1 G2/0 (4) plus R3 S3/0 (15) plus R4 G2/0 (4), for a total OSPF cost of 23 to reach the 10.45.0.0/24 network.

	Because the cost of 23 is correct, the other choices provided are incorrect.

questionText: OSPF has been configured in a single area. All the serial interfaces have a cost of 64, Fast Ethernet interfaces have an OSPF cost of 10, and the Gigabit Ethernet interfaces have a cost of 1. Which of the following is true?
explanation:
R5 calculates the OSPF cost - the metric - for all three paths from itself to subnet 10.1.0.0/24, as follows:


	The route from R5 to R4 to R3 to R2 to R1, and out the interface connected to subnet 10.1.0.0/24, uses interfaces with costs of 1, 1, 1, 1, and 10, for a total of 14.
	The route from R5 to R4 to R2 to R1, and out the interface connected to subnet 10.1.0.0/24, uses interfaces with costs of 1, 64, 1, and 10, for a total of 76.
	The route from R5 to R1, and out the interface connected to subnet 10.1.0.0/24, uses interfaces with costs of 10 and 10, for a total of 20.


Therefore, R5 uses the lowest-cost route with a cost of 14, with R5's outgoing interface of G1/0 and  R4 as the next-hop router. The facts in the previous sentence either rule in or out each answer.

answerChoices.Text: R5 uses the exit interface of Fa2/0 to reach the subnet 10.1.0.0/24.
R5’s cost to reach subnet 10.1.0.0/24 is 4.
Metrics are not used in link-state routing protocols.

questionText: Which types of LSAs will the ABR create?
OSPF-enabled routers send “Hello” packets using which multicast IP address?
explanation: OSPF routers send Hello packets using multicast address 224.0.0.5. EIGRP routers use 224.0.0.10. RIP routers use 224.0.0.9, and DHCP server/relay agents use 224.0.0.12.

questionText: Which options are stable OSPF neighbor states?
explanation:
There are two stable OSPF states: 2-way and full. If the link is not a type that uses DR/BDRs, then the only stable state would be full, but if the link type uses DR/BDRs, then it is possible for routers to exist in the 2-way state and be stable because they are available to be the BDR but are not currently the DR or BDR on a link.

	Of the incorrect answers, Exstart and Loading are correct OSPF neighbor states, but are interim states. Established is not an OSPF state (but is the correct stable state for eBGP.)

questionText: What is true when two OSPF routers both reach the two-way state of their neighbor relationship?
explanation:
A two-way state will be reached after several steps. The routers will both send Hellos, check parameters, and if the parameters match, list the neighbor's RID in subsequent Hellos. At that point, both reach a 2-way state and are ready to exchange their LSDBs.

	Note that OSPF does not use ping as any part of establishing a neighbor relationship. Also, note that if the routers had begun to exchange their LSDBs, they would have reached other OSPF neighbor states.

answerChoices.Text: Each router sees its Router ID in the hello packet sent by the neighboring router
The routers exchanged Hellos and all necessary parameters match
The routers are neighbors and are ready to exchange their LSDBs
The routers succeeded in pinging each other

questionText: Which LSA types describe the topology inside an OSPF area?
explanation: When building their Link-State Database (LSDB), OSPF routers send LSA type 1, which describes a router, and LSA type 2, which describes a network where a DR resides. These LSAs describe the topology inside the area. Type 3 LSAs define subnets in other areas and are created by ABRs.

questionText: The figure and exhibit show a router's interfaces and the associated configuration. On which interface is OSPF not active?
explanation: The first network statement turns on OSPF on interfaces that have IP addresses that look like 192.168.1.x, which includes both serial interfaces. The second statement matches fa0/1 leaving the fa0/0 as the only interface that is not actIve in the OSPF process.
comments:
10/31 - ok as-is, "I don’t want to read you much into your question, but I think that’s the core of what you’re asking. The OSPF **network** command can use any wildcard mask that works. The command’s goal is to match interfaces, and once matched, IOS enables OSPF on the matched interfaces and assigns them to the area as noted in the command. So, you can invert the subnet mask to come up with a wildcard mask to use in the network command. But you can use any other wildcard mask as well. Then IOS determines the range of addresses as computed from the address and wildcard mask in the network command, compares that range to all interfaces on the router, and for those matched, enables OSPF. So, you asked “Shouldn’t…” - there’s no should or shouldn’t, just what is, and then the job is to figure out which interfaces are matched by which network commands.

Now, if I were configuring OSPF in a real network, would I pick a convention, and use it on all routers? Yes. Might I invert the subnet mask like you did as the convention? Perfectly reasonable. But for the exams, you should know how to interpret the range of addresses etc as per above.", 10/21 - query to Au, OK-as-is, 8/22 - query to Au, CD-I2-4-52-005-1

questionText: The figure shows the IP address/mask pairs configured on some router interfaces, all in an up/up state. The exhibit shows the current output from the show ip protocols command. On how many of these interfaces has the router enabled OSPF?
explanation:
The show ip protocols command details the configuration of network commands. In this case, the output confirms the configuration of these commands. You can build these by adding the word "network" to the lines in the output under the heading "Routing for Networks:".


network 10.4.17.3 0.0.0.0 area 0
network 10.4.32.0 0.0.3.255 area 0



You can find the range of addresses matched by the commands by using the first value as the low end of the range and the sum of the first two values as the high end of the range. In this case:

First command: 10.4.17.3 – 10.4.17.3 (a single address)

Second command: 10.4.32.0 – 10.4.35.255

 

Based on these facts, you can see that the first command matches only R1's G0/0/1 interface address. The second command matches the other interfaces because the address 10.4.33.254 and 10.4.35.129 reside within the range defined by the second network command. So, the configuration enables OSPF on three of the three interfaces in the figure.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit; which options are true about the OSPF configuration?
explanation: The exhibit shows that R2 is configured into two different areas: 0 and 2. It also shows that its F0/0 interface has been configured using a network statement and its F0/1 interface has been configured using interface OSPF commands.

answerChoices.Text: R2 is configured in a single OSPF area: 0.
R2 is configured in two OSPF areas: 0 and 2.
R2’s F0/1 is configured using OSPF interface configuration.
R2’s F0/1 is configured using OSPF network configuration.

questionText: If not configured with the router-id command, what is the next option a Cisco router uses to choose its OSPF router-ID?

answerChoices.Text: Use the IP address of the active loopback interface with the highest IP address
Use the IP address of the active non-loopback interface with the highest interface ID number
Use the IP address of the active loopback interface with the highest interface ID number
Use the IP address of the active non-loopback interface with the highest IP address

questionText: Which of the following rules does an OSPF router follow with regard to the selection of a router ID (RID) when the OSPF process starts?
explanation:
The selection order for the 32-bit OSPFv2 router ID, in order of priority, is:

	
		Configured router ID
	
		Highest IPv4 address on a working loopback interface
	
		Highest IPv4 address on any other working interface


	The OSPF process will not start without a router ID, and in the absence of the three methods listed in the explanation, the router will not use the logical IPv4 loopback address of 127.0.0.1.

answerChoices.Text: In the absence of a configured RID, the router uses the highest IP address on a working loopback interface.
In the absence of a configured RID, if no loopback interface address can be used, it uses the highest IP address among all working nonloopback interfaces.

If no configured IPv4 addresses exist, and if there is no configured router ID, the router creates and uses a randomly generated ID, and uses that until either an IPv4 address is configured or until a router ID is configured.
The router uses the explcitly-configured RID if configured.
If no other rules provide the router with an RID, it uses the loopback address 127.0.0.1.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit; in which area would R1’s Gi0/0 interface be placed?
explanation: When there are multiple matching OSPF network statements that each overlap a specific interface, the one that was configured first in the configuration will be used. The exception to this is if OSPF has also been configured on the interface; when this happens the interface configuration will be prioritized over any network statements. In this case the Gi0/0 interface has been configured with an OSPF interface command placing it into area 22.

questionText: Review the topology. All subnets exist in OSPF area 0. Which command, if issued on R3, would show all the LSAs known by R3?
explanation:
The command show ip ospf database will show the LSAs known by that router.

	The show running-config, show ip ospf interface, show ip ospf neighbors, and show ip route ospf commands are all valid commands that can assist in the verification and troubleshooting of OSPF, but they do not show the LSAs known to the router in OSPF.

questionText: Her boss asks a junior engineer to suggest a single OSPF network command to use on router R1 in the figure. The goal: match all three interfaces with the one network command. The command must also follow all command conventions so that IOS will not change the command when the engineer adds it to the configuration. Which answer meets all the requirements?
explanation:
The question requires that the command not be changed by IOS when added to the router configuration. In some cases, IOS will change the subnet value (the first value) in the OSPF network command when you add it to the configuration. By convention, the first numeric value must be the numerically lowest number in the range defined by the combined subnet plus wildcard fields. If not, IOS changes your value to the lowest number in the range. 

For instance, in this case, the network 172.16.30.1 0.0.0.255 area 0 command defines a range with the idea of "all addresses that begin 172.16.30". Numerically, the range is 172.16.30.0 – 172.16.30.255. However, with an initial value of 172.16.30.1, which is not the number at the low end of the range, IOS would change the command to network 172.16.30.0 0.0.0.255 area 0.

Two incorrect answers have values in the subnet field that would result in IOS changing the command, making them incorrect based on the wording of this question:

network 172.16.30.1 0.0.0.255… becomes network 172.16.30.0 0.0.0.255…

network 172.16.30.1 0.0.1.255… becomes network 172.16.30.0 0.0.1.255…

For the two remaining answers, one creates an address range that includes all three interfaces, and one matches only two interfaces, not matching interface G0/0/0's IP address. You can easily find the range of values matched by the network command. Once in the configuration file, the command has the number at the low end of the range as the first value. You simply add the two values (subnet and wildcard mask) to find the high end of the range. In this case:

network 172.16.30.0 0.0.0.255… has a range of: 172.16.30.0 – 172.16.30.255

network 172.16.30.0 0.0.1.255… has a range of: 172.16.30.0 – 172.16.31.255

Based on comparing those ranges to the interface addresses, only the network 172.16.30.0 0.0.1.255… command matches all three interfaces.

questionText: The exhibit shows output from router R1. Which answers give conclusions about OSPF on router R1 that must be true based only on that output? (Choose two answers.)

answerChoices.Text: R1 has OSPF neighbor relationships with two or more routers.
R1 has OSPF neighbor relationships with less than two routers.
You cannot know how many OSPF neighbor relationships R1 has.
R1 has two or more OSPF network subcommands.
R1 has two or more ip ospf 1 area 0 interface subcommands.
R1 has two or more ip ospf 0 area 1 interface subcommands.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. R2 has a router ID of 2.2.2.2. If the DR loses power, which routers could compete in the election to become the BDR?
explanation:
The output in the exhibit, plus the information in the question, can lead you to these conclusions:

	
		The router with router ID 1.1.1.1 is the current DR, as noted by the "FULL/DR" state.
	
		The router with router ID 4.4.4.4 is the BDR, as noted by the "FULL/BDR" state.
	
		Router 3.3.3.3 is a DROther.
	
		Router 2.2.2.2 is implied to also be a DROther, as the DR and BDR are already identified.


	Next, note that when both a DR and BDR exist, when the DR fails, the BDR takes over as DR, with no election of the DR. At that point, a new BDR is elected from the remaining routers. In this case:

	
		1.1.1.1, the former DR, is powerd off and unavilable.
	
		4.4.4.4, the former BDR, is now DR and not a part of the BDR election.
	
		2.2.2.2 and 3.3.3.3, former DROther routers, compete to be elected BDR.

questionText: What commands will configure an OSPF point-to-point network type?
explanation:
The commands to configure an OSFP point-to-point network type are

R1(config)# interface fa0/1
R1(config-if)# ip ospf network point-to-point

answerChoices.Text:
R1(config)# interface fa0/1
R1(config-if)# ip ospf network point-to-point

R1(config)# interface fa0/1
R1(config-if)# no ip ospf network broadcast

R1(config)# interface fa0/1
R1(config-if)# ip network point-to-point

questionText: The exhibit shows output from local router R1. Which answers list an OSPF router adjacent to router R1 on its Fa0/0 interface?
explanation:
The show ip ospf interface command output lists the OSPF router IDs (RIDs) of fully adjacent neighbors towards the end of the output. The exhibit lists these lines:

   Adjacent with neighbor 172.31.12.201  (Designated Router)
   Adjacent with neighbor 172.31.230.3   (Backup Designated Router)

	These two lines confirm the RIDs of the two adjacent neighbors off R1's F0/0 port.

	Of the two incorrect answers that list dotted decimal numbers, neither is listed in the list of adjacent neighbors, making them incorrect. Note that one answer, 10.1.5.2, is listed as the local router's own RID, so it could never be listed also as an adjcent neighbor, as a router cannot be a neighbor to itself.

	Finally, on the answer that suggests that you cannot know the answer, the output does list all the adjcent neighbors on the interface, so the question can be answered using the output.

answerChoices.Text: It is impossible to tell definitively from the information given.

questionText: Which Cisco IOS command is used to advertise a default route into an OSPFv2 domain regardless of whether a default static route is configured?
explanation:
The default-information originate command is used to broadcast a default route throughout the OSPF domain. To work correctly, either:

	
		The router configured with the default-information originate command must also have a default route in its routing table
	
		The default-information originate command must include the always parameter.


	Of these, the one with the always parameter is correct, given that the question requires that the default route must always be advertised.

	The two other incorrect options list invalid paramters at the end of each command.

questionText: Which of the following statements is true regarding how OSPF derives the cost of an interface?
explanation: The formula to calculate OSPF costs, which is used when the ip ospf cost command is not configured on an interface, is 10^8 / bandwidth. The auto-cost command value defaults to a setting of 100, meaning 100 Mbps, which is equal to 10^8, and is the numerator of the formula. Therefore, an auto-cost reference-bandwidth 100 command simply sets the value to its default setting. In contrast, auto-cost reference-bandwidth 1000 increases the numerator in the formula by a factor of 10.

answerChoices.Text: The cost can be set to 50 for serial 0/0 using the ip ospf cost 50 serial 0/0 global configuration command.
The cost can be set to 50 for serial 0/0 using the ip ospf cost 50 interface subcommand on s0/0.
On a serial interface with a default bandwidth setting, the OSPF cost is 64.
Assuming that the setting previously used the default, the auto-cost reference-bandwidth 100 configuration command would increase the previously calculated OSPF costs by a factor of 10.
Assuming that the setting previously used the default, the auto-cost reference-bandwidth 1000 configuration command would increase the previously calculated OSPF costs by a factor of 10.

questionText: Which OSPF command will display the OSPF network type that a specific interface uses?
explanation:
The command show ip ospf interface g0/1 will display the OSPF network type.

	
Router1# show ip ospf interface g0/1
GigabitEthernet0/1 is up, line protocol is up
 Internet Address 10.10.10.1/24, Area 0
 Process ID 1, Router ID 192.168.1.1, Network Type BROADCAST, Cost: 10
 Transmit Delay is 1 sec, State BDR, Priority 1

questionText: Four OSPF routers connect to the same LAN. In a new election after all routers have been rebooted, which router wins the DR election?
explanation:
First, the DR election always chooses the BDR to become the DR if a BDR exists. However, the question states that all the routers just rebooted, so there should be no BDR to take over for the DR. As worded, the question creates a scenario where all routers compete equally to become DR.

	The routers choose the router with the highest OSPF interface priority, and if a tie, they then use the router with the highest router ID. In this case, the answers show routers with different priorities, so no ties exist based on priority. As a result, R1, with the highest priority (4), becomes the DR.

questionText: Refer to the diagram and exhibit. Which answer best describes the route that router R1 would use to forward packets towards the Internet?
explanation: The default-information originate command advertises a default route throughout the OSPF domain. A working default route must exist on the router with the default-information originate command for the command to work correctly. R3 meets this requirement using a default static route to 192.0.2.1, an address located off R3's G0/1 interface. R3 then advertises a default route into the OSPF domain as an external route. As OSPF propagates the route from router to router, each router alters the next-hop to reflect the next upstream router's address. For instance, R3 would advertise a default route with a next-hop of 10.10.10.1, and R2 would advertise it with a next-hop of 20.20.20.1. As a result, the default route on router R1 will list 20.20.20.1 as its next-hop address.
comments:
8/4 - query to Au

2/4 - "the next-hop addresses are not in the figure. They are found in the exhibit, which lists relevant router configuration for this question."  2/2 - query to Au, 12/17 - ok as-is, " think about the perspective from the branch router. The IP routes on a router list the neighboring router’s IP address, specifically the IP address on the link that connects the two routers. In this case:

A route w/ “Central Site” as the next hop will list Central Site’s Fa0/1 IP address of 50.50.50.1.
A route w/ “Central Site Backup” as the next hop will list Central Site Backup’s S1/0 IP address of 150.150.150.1.

So, to answer your specific question, 100.100.100.2 is incorrect as it is the Central Site Backup  router’s IP address on its F0/0 interface, an interface that is not connected a link w/ the Branch router.
As for why 150.150.150.1 is correct, that’s an address on a neighboring router on a link connected to the Branch router."  , 12/14 - query to Au

answerChoices.Text: None, because the route wouldn’t exist

questionText: Refer to the exhibit; in which area would R1’s Gi0/0 interface be placed?
explanation: When there are multiple matching OSPF network statements that each overlap a specific interface, the one that was configured first in the configuration will be used. In this case the first matching statement places the interface into area 5.

questionText: A router configuration uses the default reference bandwidth setting and also uses OSPF cost defaults as calculated by the router. Analyzing the exhibit's output for interface serial 1, which answer lists the approximate interface bandwidth of that interface?
explanation:
First, note that the output of the show ip ospf interface command lists a cost of 64, and the default setting on the auto-cost reference-bandwidth OSPF configuration command is 100, meaning 100 Mbps. Finally, IOS uses a default OSPF cost calculation of:

reference_bandwidth / interface_bandwidth

Next, the formula needs to use consistent units, so using bits per second:

100,000,000 bps / interface_bandwidth bps = 64

Solving for interface_bandwidth:

interface_bandwidth = 100,000,000 / 64 = 1,562,500. Among the answers, it is closest to 1,500,000 bps = 1500 kbps = 1.5 mbps.
comments: 10/1 - ok as-is "Looking in the book at Table 20-3 in Volume 1, there is no table entry for 512 Kbps. There is an entry for 1544 Kbps, with cost 64, which matches the question’s details. 1544 Kbps, converted to units of Megabits/second (Mbps), is 1.544 Mbps." , 9/29 - query to Au, typo, CD-I2-4-52-008-1

questionText: Given the output from a working OSPF router, as seen in the exhibit, how many neighboring routers exist?
explanation: Notice that two different router IDs are listed. 192.168.22.1 is  connected via f0/0 and s1/0. Router ID is significant because it  uniquely identifies each router. In this case, the router on which the  command output was gathered has two links connecting it to the router  with router ID 192.168.22.1—namely, this router's f0/0 and s1/0  interfaces. So, while 3 neighbor relationships exist, there are only 2  different neighboring routers.

questionText: What command can you use to verify the neighbor adjacencies of an OSPF router?
explanation:
The show ip ospf neighbor command will show the neighbor ID, state, address, and interface. It is the best command to verify if a specific neighbor relationship has been established.

	The show ospf interface brief command is not a supported Cisco IOS command.

	The show ip ospf database command shows all the entries in the OSPF link-state database and the information taken from the LSAs that have been received. However, it does not reveal any OSPF neighbor status information.

	The show running-config command will show the configuration of OSPF, but it does not show any status information, including OSPF neighbor status.

questionText: What are two configurable settings that can influence the DR/BDR election?

Refer to the exhibit. Routers R2, R3, and R4, connected to the same LAN, boot and work to exchange OSPF routes for a month. Later, R1 boots and joins the same LAN. Which devices now serve as DR and BDR for the link?
explanation:
OSPF routers elect the DR and BDR based on the highest RID among the routers actively negotiating on the specific link. Initially, R2, R3, and R4 compete with their RIDs of 10.1.1.2, 10.1.1.3, and 10.1.1.4, respectively, based on each router's numerically-highest OSPF Router IDs. With the configuration shown, the routers all use the IP addresses on their loopback interfaces as router ID. (Note that none of the routers configured their RIDs directly.) As a result of R4 having the numerically-highest RID, R4 becomes DR. R3, with the next highest RID, becomes the BDR.

	Note that the addition of a new router to the LAN (R1) does not cause the routers to elect a new DR or BDR. Only the failure of a DR or BDR on the LAN causes a new election.

answerChoices.Text: R2 is the DR, R3 is the BDR.
R1 is the DR, R2 is the BDR.
R4 is the DR, R3 is the BDR.
R4 is the DR, R1 is the BDR.

questionText: In the output shown in the exhibit, what does the – mean under the State heading?
explanation: The output under the state heading lists the OSPF neighbor state, then a /, and then additonal information. If the interface associated with the neighbor does not use a DR/BDR concept, the output lists a simple -. If it does use a DR or BDR, it lists the neighbor's state as DR, BDR, or DROther. The - simply means that the interface will not elect a DR at all. The three incorrect answers all refer to cases in which a DR has been elected, or is in the process of being elected.

questionText: In the absence of a direct cost being configured for an OSPF interface, and using the default reference OSPF bandwidth, what is the OSPF cost for a Fast Ethernet interface operating at 100 Mbps?
explanation:
