OSPF cost is calculated by dividing a reference bandwidth by the actual bandwidth of the interface: 100,000 / 100,000 = 1.

	If the reference bandwidth were increased from the default (doubled, for example), the calculated cost of that same interface would be higher.

questionText: Which statement is true about the DR and BDR in OSPF?
explanation: If the DR fails, the BDR becomes the DR, and an election will occur for a new BDR. If the DR comes back online, it will not resume as DR. There will not be another DR election because the BDR has become the DR upon failure of the original DR. The new election occurs for the BDR, not the DR.

answerChoices.Text: If the DR fails, the BDR becomes the DR, and an election will occur for a new BDR.
If the DR fails, an election will occur for a new DR.
If the DR fails, the BDR becomes the DR, and no new election will occur for the BDR.
If the DR fails, the BDR becomes the DR, and when the DR is online again, it will resume as the DR.

questionText:
A router lists the following partial output from the show ip route command. Out which interface will the router route packets destined to IP address 10.1.15.122?


     10.0.0.0/8 is variably subnetted, 8 subnets, 5 masks
O       10.1.15.100/32 [110/50] via 172.16.25.2, 00:00:04, GigabitEthernet0/0/0
O       10.1.15.64/26 [110/100] via 172.16.25.129, 00:00:09, GigabitEthernet0/1/0
O       10.1.14.0/23 [110/65] via 172.16.24.2, 00:00:04, GigabitEthernet0/2/0
O       10.1.15.96/27 [110/65] via 172.16.24.129, 00:00:09, GigabitEthernet0/3/0
O       0.0.0.0/0 [110/129] via 172.16.25.129, 00:00:09, GigabitEthernet0/0/0
explanation: Destination address 10.1.15.122 matches all the routes listed except the host route to 10.1.15.100/32. In that case, the router will choose the matching route with the longest prefix length - the prefix-style mask with the highest number. In this case, that route lists subnet 10.1.15.96 and mask /27, which lists interface G0/3/0 as the outgoing interface.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. Which of the displayed routes would be used for traffic destined for 50.100.140.25?
explanation:
Of the routes for the 50.100.128.0 network shown, two of them would match for the 50.100.140.25 destination: 50.100.128.0/17 and 50.100.128.0/18. The 50.100.128.0/21 and 50.100.128.0/24 routes would not match the 50.100.128.0 destination because they don't include the destination 50.100.140.25:

	
		The 50.100.128.0/21 network includes the addresses 50.100.128.0 through 50.100.135.255, inclusively;
	
		The 50.100.128.0/24 network includes the addresses 50.100.128.0 through 50.100.128.255, inclusively.


	Note that the router would use the route to subnet 50.100.128.0/18 because it is the more specific route, that is, it has a longer prefix-length mask (/18 as compared to /17).

questionText:
The configuration excerpt below shows the OSPF interface configuration for the WAN interface that connects routers R1 and R2 in the figure. The WAN link works, and a ping of the IP address on the opposite end of the link works from each router. Which answer best describes the output you expect to find in this case? (Choose two answers.)


On R1: 
interface GigabitEthernet0/0/1
  ip address 10.1.12.1 255.255.255.0
  ip ospf 1 area 0

On R2: 
interface GigabitEthernet0/0/0
  ip address 10.1.12.2 255.255.255.0
  ip ospf 1 area 0
  ip ospf network point-to-point
explanation:
The configuration shows a difference in the OSPF network type setting, with R1 using the default (broadcast) and R2 using point-to-point. In that case, the two routers reach the point of becoming neighbors. On R1 and R2, the show ip ospf neighbor command would list the other router. They even exchange LSAs and reach a "FULL" state.

However, the routers cannot correctly process the LSAs because of the mismatch, so they do not add any routes to their respective routing tables based on the learned LSAs. So, R2 will not list a route for subnet 10.1.1.0/24, and R1 will not list a route for subnet 10.1.2.0/24.

answerChoices.Text: R1 continuously lists R2 as a router in the list of OSPF neighbors.
R1 flips from listing R2 and then not listing it as a router in the list of OSPF neighbors.
R1 never lists R2 as a router in the list of OSPF neighbors.
R2 lists an IP route to subnet 10.1.1.0/24.
R2 does not list an IP route to subnet 10.1.1.0/24.

questionText: A router in an enterprise network uses OSPF, enabled on five different interfaces using the ip ospf 1 area 0 interface subcommand in each case. An engineer wants to disable OSPF operations on interface G0/0/2 while causing the least disruption. The engineer cannot remove the ip ospf 1 area 0 interface subcommand by policy.  Which answer suggests the best option?
explanation:
Only one answer lists a solution that would not disable OSPF on the interface: The answer with the shutdown g0/0/2 command. The command does not exist in IOS.

Of the three other answers that include "shutdown," all would cause OSPF to stop operating on interface G0/0/2. However, the correct answer causes the least disruption. Working through those three:


	shutdown in OSPF mode: stop all OSPF operations for the process, which per the question, means stopping OSPF for all interfaces.
	shutdown in interface mode: stop all traffic on the interface, whether it would use an OSPF route or not.
	ip ospf shutdown in interface mode: stop all OSPF operations on the interface. This option provides the same feature described in the question.


The final incorrect answer, reload, stops all OSPF operations on the router by reinitializing IOS.

answerChoices.Text: Issue the shutdown command in OSPF process 1 configuration mode.
Issue the shutdown command in interface G0/0/2 configuration mode.
Issue the shutdown g0/0/2 command in OSPF process 1 configuration mode.
Issue the ip ospf shutdown command in interface G0/0/2 configuration mode.
Issue the reload command in privileged EXEC mode.

questionText: Routers R1 and R2 connect to the same point-to-point Ethernet WAN link. The two routers use OSPF. Some misconfigurations and operational status values would prevent R1 from listing R2's OSPF router ID in the show ip ospf command output.  Which answers list such a configuration or status? (Choose three answers.)
explanation:
Some misconfiguration and status issues do not cause a problem for OSPF neighbors. Others cause a problem so that a router does not list the potential neighbor as a neighbor in the output of the show ip ospf neighbor command. Some other problems prevent the neighbor relationship from working correctly, but the neighbor appears in the command output. This question reviews some of the reasons for each category.

The correct answers identify configuration or status that confirms that R1 and R2 will not have an OSPF neighbor relationship and that router R1 does not list R2's RID in the list of neighbors. The incorrect answer that mentions that both routers have an interface state of up/up is not a problem but rather a confirmation that the link works correctly. The other incorrect answer is not a problem for OSPF and does not cause any OSPF neighbor failures.

answerChoices.Text: Interfaces on opposite ends of the link are in an up/up state.
An inbound ACL on R2's end of the link discards OSPF messages
The WAN link endpoints use IP addresses in different subnets.
The R2 OSPF process is shutdown.
R1 and R2 use different OSPF process IDs.

questionText: Routers R1 and R2 connect to the same point-to-point Ethernet WAN link. The two routers use OSPF. Some misconfigurations and operational status values would prevent R1 from listing R2's OSPF router ID in the show ip ospf command output.  Which answers list such a configuration or status? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
Some misconfiguration and status issues do not cause a problem for OSPF neighbors. Others cause a problem so that a router does not list the potential neighbor as a neighbor in the output of the show ip ospf neighbor command. Some other problems prevent the neighbor relationship from working correctly, but the neighbor appears in the command output. This question reviews some of the reasons for each category.

The correct answers identify configuration or status that confirms that R1 and R2 will not have an OSPF neighbor relationship and that router R1 does not list R2's RID in the list of neighbors. All routers on the same link/subnet must be in the same OSPF area, and one answer describes configuration that places the ends of the link in different areas. The other correct answer describes an allowed case of both routers using OSPF Process ID 1, but a disallowed case of both routers using the same router ID (1.1.1.1.) 

For the incorrect answers, two refer to conditions that do not result in any problem at all. Both require that you recall some default settings. First, R1 uses 9 for priority, and R2 defaults to use 1. The numbers can be the same or different; the priority values only cause a failure if you set both to 0. The answer with the ip ospf dead-interval 40 interface subcommand sets the configuration value to the same value as the default setting on the other router, so that does not cause a problem.

Finally, one incorrect answer is incorrect because, although it does cause a problem, R1 does display R2's RID in the neighbor table. In that case, the two routers become neighbors and exchange LSAs, but they cannot build routes based on those LSAs due to the network type mismatch.

answerChoices.Text: R1's WAN interface is in area 1, and R2's WAN interface is in area 0.
R1 uses the default OSPF network type, and R2 uses network type point-to-point.
Both routers use OSPF process ID 1 and Router ID 1.1.1.1.
The network engineer configured one command related to OSPF timers: the ip ospf dead-interval 40 subcommand on R2's WAN link.
The network engineer configured the ip ospf shutdown subcommand, followed by the no shutdown subcommand, on R2's WAN link.

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. Which of the displayed routes would be used for traffic destined for 100.100.100.50?
explanation:
Of the routes for the 100.100.0.0 network shown, three of them would match for the 100.100.100.50 destination:

	100.100.0.0/14 (range 100.100.0.0 - 100.103.255.255)

	100.100.0.0/16 (range 100.100.0.0 - 100.100.255.255)

	100.100.0.0/17 (range 100.100.0.0 - 100.100.127.255)

	Of those three routes the router would use 100.100.0.0/17 because it is the more specific route.

	As for the incorrect answer, the 100.100.0.0/21 route would not match the 100.100.100.50 destination because it would include only the addresses from 100.100.0.0 through 100.100.7.255, inclusively.

questionText: All routers in the figure use OSPF with all interfaces in area 0. All links work, and OSPF works as usual. All configuration settings have a useful default value use that default setting. Which answer best describes the contents of router R1's IP routing table regarding subnet 172.16.30.192/26?
explanation:
With all default settings, the OSPF interface costs of all the Gigabit interfaces default to cost 1. The cost from R1 to subnet 172.16.30.192/26 is 2 over both routes (through R2 and R3.) R1 also has a default OSPF subcommand setting of maximum-paths 4, or at least a default with a value of more than 1.

Combining these facts, R1 will calculate two routes for the subnet, find both OSPF routes have an equal metric, and due to the maximum-paths setting, it will add both routes to the routing table. Both will be stable and remain in the table. By default, the router will load balance traffic across the two routes on a destination-by-destination basis.

answerChoices.Text: R1 has no routes to subnet 172.16.30.192/26
R1 has one stable route to subnet 172.16.30.192/26 using R2 as the next-hop router
R1 has one stable route to subnet 172.16.30.192/26, but we cannot know which router it uses as the next-hop router
R1 has two stable routes to subnet 172.16.30.192/26, using R2 and R3 as next-hop routers

questionText:
All links in the figure work with valid IP addresses. The two configuration lines below exist on all three routers, with no other non-default OSPF settings on any of the three routers. As a result, R1 lists two neighbor relationships. An engineer considers adding the commands described in the answers to router R1's configuration. Which answers would result in a failure of at least one OSPF neighbor relationship?


router ospf 1
  network 0.0.0.0 255.255.255.255 area 0
explanation:
The configuration enables OSPF on all interfaces and assigns them to area 0 per the configured network command. Also, as worded, all routers will use the default values for all other OSPF settings. For each answer, you need to decide if the configuration change would impact R1's neighbor relationship with either R2 or R3, with the correct answers being those that cause a problem. Working through the correct answers:


	The answer that changes R1's G0/0/1 Hello interval to 11, instead of the default used by neighbor R2 of 10, causes the existing neighbor relationship to fail. Neighbors must use the same Hello and Dead intervals. 
	The answer with the ip ospf shutdown interface subcommand on R1's G0/0/1 interface disables all OSPF processing. As a result, R1's neighbor relationship with R2 fails.
	The answer that describes an inbound ACL on router R1's G0/0/2 interface, which filters all OSPF Hello messages, causes the neighbor relationships on that interface to fail. OSPF uses the continual receipt of Hello messages to indicate that the neighbor is still up and working.


As for the incorrect answers – those that do not cause a problem:


	All the routers use Ethernet-type interfaces, which use a default broadcast network type. The ip ospf network broadcast command just reconfigures the default setting and does not make a change.
	The answer with the ip ospf shutdown interface subcommand on R1's G0/0/0 interface disables all OSPF processing. However, R1 has no OSPF neighbors off that interface, so the configuration change does not result in any neighbor failures, making this answer incorrect for this question.

answerChoices.Text: Adding ip ospf hello-interval 11 subcommand to R1's G0/0/1 interface.
Adding the ip ospf network broadcast subcommand to R1's G0/0/2 interface.
Adding ip ospf shutdown subcommand to R1's G0/0/2 interface.
Adding the ip ospf shutdown subcommand on R1's G0/0/0 interface.
Adding an ACL to R1 that discards all incoming OSPF Hello messages on its G0/0/2 interface.

questionText: What will happen if two OSPF routers have different MTU sizes?
explanation: If two OSPF routers have different MTU sizes, they can still form a neighbor relationship, but they will not be able to exchange their LSDBs; therefore, they won’t exchange routes. After a certain time, the neighbor relationship will fail also. The routers will not be able to exchange routes. MTU sizes will not change the hello/dead timers or the RIDs.

answerChoices.Text: They will fail to exchange their LSDBs.

questionText: OSPF routers can hear Hellos from another router, but not form neighbor relationships. Which of the following definitely prevent neighbor relationships from being formed?
explanation:
Two two correct answers do list two separate reasons why two routers would not become OSPF neighbors.
	
	As for the wrong answers, the dead intervals must match for the routers to become neighbors, and the dead interval defaults to four times the Hello interval, but the dead interval does not have to be four times the Hello interval. Next, the network commands on the two routers do not have to match in any way at all; the only requirement is that both routers have OSPF enabled on the interfaces somehow. Finally, OSPF uses interface IP addresses and multicast addresses as the source and destination of OSPF packets, often which do not happen to be the OSPF RID, so an ACL that matches the RID would not necessarily stop OSPF from working.

answerChoices.Text: An ip ospf access-group 101 in command on the interface, with ACL 101 filtering the RID of the other router
Mismatched networks listed in the configured network commands
When both routers have the same configured dead interval, but with the dead interval not being four times the Hello interval

questionText: Which options do not prevent a directly connected OSPF speaker from becoming a neighbor?
explanation: The OSPF process IDs on neighboring routers do not have to match. However, the area number, the subnet mask, the subnet in which the routers' IP addresses exist, and the Dead and Hello timers must match.

questionText: What is the default Dead interval timer for an OSPF router?
explanation: By default, the Dead interval timer is four times the “Hello” timer.

questionText:
The configuration excerpt below shows the OSPF interface configuration for the WAN interface that connects routers R1 and R2 in the figure. The WAN link works, and a ping of the IP address on the opposite end of the link works from each router. Which answer best describes the output you expect to find in this case? (Choose two answers.)


On R1: 
interface GigabitEthernet0/0/1
  ip address 10.1.12.1 255.255.255.0
  ip ospf 1 area 0

On R2: 
interface GigabitEthernet0/0/0
  ip address 10.1.12.2 255.255.255.0
  ip ospf 1 area 0
  ip mtu 1600
explanation:
Cisco router interfaces default to use an IP MTU of 1500 bytes. Combining the default setting on R1's G0/0/1 with the configuration on R2's G0/0/0 MTU of 1600 creates an MTU mismatch. With OSPF, the routers attempt to become neighbors, listing each other for a time in the output of the show ip ospf neighbor command. However, the neighbor relationship fails due to the MTU mismatch, so the routers remove the neighbor table entry. The routers repeat this process over and over.

The routers fail to exchange any LSAs, so they add no routes. So, R2 will not list a route for subnet 10.1.1.0/24, and R1 will not list a route for subnet 10.1.2.0/24.

answerChoices.Text: R1 continuously lists R2 as a router in the list of OSPF neighbors.
R1 alternates between listing R2, and then not listing R2, as a router in the OSPF neighbor list.
R1 never lists R2 as a router in the list of OSPF neighbors.
R2 lists an IP route to subnet 10.1.1.0/24.
R2 does not list an IP route to subnet 10.1.1.0/24.

questionText: An engineer has been given the following diagram and must configure all the routers correctly. After configuring the routers, the engineer finds that R1 and R2 are unable to establish an OSPF adjacency. Which two of the following could be possible causes?

answerChoices.Text: The routers use different OSPF Hello and Dead intervals.
The two routers use different OSPF process ID settings.
Router R1 has a static IP route that references R2 as the next-hop router.
The OSPF area setting for each router's LAN interface uses a different OSPF area.

questionText: Which answers list a requirement for an OSPF neighbor relationship?
explanation:
To have an OSPF neighbor relationship, certain criteria must be matched:

	- Interfaces must be in the same subnet.
	- Hello/dead timers must match on all routers.
	- OSPF process must be up and not shut down.
	- Routers need to be in the same area.
	- Router IDs must be unique.
	- If authentication is used, routers must have same password.
	- Interfaces must be in the up/up state.
	- ACLs cannot block routing protocol.

	Although the neighboring interfaces in OSPF should use the same network type, it will not stop a neighbor relationship. All routers need a unique RID.

answerChoices.Text: Interfaces must be in the same subnet.
The router IDs must be identical.
Interfaces must use the same network type.

questionText: A command reveals a router interface with a bandwidth of 1 Mbps. If not set using additional configuration, what cost will OSPF assign to the interface?
explanation: Although the RFC does not specify how cost is determined, Cisco defaults to a value that is inversely proportional to 100 Mbps. Because 100 Mbps / 1 Mbps = 100, the cost of this link would be 100.

questionText: There are two directly connected OSPF configured routers. What will happen if you accidentally configure one OSPF router with a network type as broadcast and the other router with a network type as point-to-point?
explanation:
If you accidentally configure one OSPF router with a network type as broadcast and the other router with a network type as point-to-point:
	- Both routers will exchange their LSDB.
	- Both routers will reach full state.
	- Neither router will add IP routes to the routing tables.

answerChoices.Text: Both routers will exchange their LSDB.
Both routers will reach full state.
Neither router will add IP routes to their routing tables.

questionText: R1, R2, R3, and R4 have their Fast Ethernet 0/0 interfaces attached to the same VLAN. A network engineer has typed a configuration for each router by using a word processor. He will later copy and paste the configuration into the routers. Examine the following exhibit, which lists configuration for the four routers, as typed by the network engineer. Assuming that all four routers can ping each other’s LAN IP addresses after the configuration has been applied, choose the routers that will be able to form a neighbor relationship with the other routers on the LAN. (You can assume that, if not shown in the exhibit, all other related parameters are still set to their defaults.)
explanation: R1 uses an OSPF process ID of 0, which is invalid, so that command will be rejected when the engineer pastes the configuration into the router. R2 and R4 have correct configurations, including the fact that their OSPF Process IDs do not have to match. R3 uses a wildcard mask of 0.0.0.0, meaning that R3 should exactly match an IP address on an interface, but the number listed in the network command (10.1.1.0) does not exactly match fa0/0's IP address (10.1.1.3).

answerChoices.Text: None of the routers will exchange routing information.

questionText: An engineer builds the network shown in the figure. All links work, and all routers successfully use OSPF in a single-area design. Consider the routes on router R1. Which answers list a routing protocol legend code you would expect to see listed for the route to the subnet listed in each answer? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The figure shows interface IP addresses rather than subnets, so part of your task is to interpret the numbers to find the subnet IDs. The Subnet IDs and masks are:

•    10.1.1.0/24 (R1 G0/0/0)
•    10.1.12.0/30 (R1-R2 link)
•    10.1.13.0/30 (R1-R3 link)
•    10.1.14.0/30 (R1-R4 link)
•    10.1.2.0/24 (R2)
•    10.1.3.0/24 (R3)
•    10.1.4.0/24 (R4)

For the three subnets on the right, router R1 will learn routes using OSPF. With a single area, those routes appear in R1's routing table with code O, as noted with the correct answer that lists subnet 10.1.3.0/24. A different (incorrect) answer lists code O for subnet 10.1.12.0/30. That subnet connects to one of router R1's interfaces, so it would not be an OSPF-learned route, but rather a connected route on router R1 (with code C.) 

For router R1's four interfaces, the router will list a connected route for each subnet, each with code C. Those facts confirm the correct answer that shows code C with subnet 10.1.1.0/24. 

Finally, a router adds a local route (code L) for the specific interface address, with prefix length /32, for each working interface. None of the correct answers lists code L with a /32 prefix length.

The incorrect answer that lists code D is incorrect because D refers to EIGRP-learned routes, and the network does not use EIGRP.
comments: Orignally 200301-WO-v1-1-app-001-1 with the 2023 exam updates new questions.

questionText: One router learns multiple different routes, with multiple routing protocols, for the exact same destination IPv4 subnet/mask. The answers list all the routing protocols used; which answer lists the routing protocol whose route would be chosen as best and added to the IPv4 routing table?
explanation: In situations where multiple routes exist to the same destination/mask from multiple sources, a tie-breaking mechanism must exist. On Cisco devices, the tie-breaking mechanism is administrative distance. Of the available options, eBGP has an administrative distance of 20, EIGRP has an administrative distance of 90, OSPF has an administrative distance of 110, and RIP has an administrative distance of 120. The source with the lower value is preferred over the others, giving the route sourced from eBGP with the priority.

questionText:
Router R1 learns the following routes:

•    A route for subnet 10.9.1.0/26 using EIGRP
•    A route for subnet 10.9.2.0/23 using OSPF (with a single area)
•    A route for subnet 10.9.4.0/24 as a connected route
•    A route for subnet 10.9.1.0/24 due to static route command ip route 10.9.1.0 255.255.255.0 10.9.4.4

Router R1 learns no other routes which impact this question, and no unstated problems exist that would prevent the router from adding these routes to the routing table. Which answers identify the routing protocol code and whether the router adds the route to its routing table? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The four routes mentioned in the question all refer to different subnets, so router R1 will add a route for all subnets to the routing table. Of note, the EIGRP route to subnet 10.9.1.0/26 and the static route to 10.9.1.0/24 overlap - but they refer to different subnets because they have different masks. So the router treats them as different subnets and will add routes to both to its routing table. In summary, the router will add routes to all four subnets, a fact that rules out as incorrect the one answer that claims a subnet does not appear in the routing table.

Of the four answers that mention a subnet and a legend code, two refer to a subnet and the correct routing protocol code (O for OSPF for the route to subnet 10.9.2.0/23 and S for static for the route to subnet 10.9.1.0/24.) One lists the incorrect routing protocol code (E for EIGRP is incorrect; EIGRP's code is D.) The other incorrect answer lists L for the connected route to subnet 10.9.4.0/24; connected routes use code C.

answerChoices.Text: The route to subnet 10.9.1.0/26 appears with legend code E
The route to subnet 10.9.2.0/23 appears with legend code O
The route to subnet 10.9.4.0/24 appears with legend code L
The route to subnet 10.9.1.0/24 appears with legend code S
The route to subnet 10.9.1.0/24 does not appear in the routing table

questionText: Routers R1 and R2 connect to the same point-to-point Ethernet WAN link. The two routers use OSPF. Some misconfigurations and operational status values would prevent R1 from listing R2's OSPF router ID in the show ip ospf command output.  Which answers list such a configuration or status? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
Some misconfiguration and status issues do not cause a problem for OSPF neighbors. Others cause a problem so that a router does not list the potential neighbor as a neighbor in the output of the show ip ospf neighbor command. Some other problems prevent the neighbor relationship from working correctly, but the neighbor appears in the command output. This question reviews some of the reasons for each category.

The correct answers identify configuration or status that confirms that R1 and R2 will not have an OSPF neighbor relationship and that router R1 does not list R2's RID in the list of neighbors. All routers on the same link/subnet must be in the same OSPF area, and one answer describes configuration that places the ends of the link in different areas. The other correct answer describes an allowed case of both routers using OSPF Process ID 1, but a disallowed case of both routers using the same router ID (1.1.1.1.) 

For the incorrect answers, two refer to conditions that do not result in any problem at all. Both require that you recall some default settings. First, R1 uses 9 for priority, and R2 defaults to use 1. The numbers can be the same or different; the priority values only cause a failure if you set both to 0. The answer with the ip ospf dead-interval 40 interface subcommand sets the configuration value to the same value as the default setting on the other router, so that does not cause a problem.

Finally, one incorrect answer is incorrect because, although it does cause a problem, R1 does display R2's RID in the neighbor table. In that case, the two routers become neighbors and exchange LSAs, but they cannot build routes based on those LSAs due to the network type mismatch.

answerChoices.Text: R1's WAN interface is in area 1, and R2's WAN interface is in area 0.
R1 uses the default OSPF network type, and R2 uses network type point-to-point.
Both routers use OSPF process ID 1 and Router ID 1.1.1.1.
The network engineer configured one command related to OSPF timers: the ip ospf dead-interval 40 subcommand on R2's WAN link.
R1 uses OSPF priority 9, and R2 uses the default setting.

questionText: Imagine you configured OSPFv2 in a small lab network. Which of the following answers list a reason why the routers in your lab would not learn all the routes  to all the IPv4 subnets (or networks) in your small lab network?
explanation:
As for the answers that could be a root cause of a problem (and are therefore correct answers to this question):

	- ACLs could block OSPF messages, which would prevent neighbors from forming adjacencies and therefore prevent the advertisements from being sent from an OSPF router. 

	- OSPFv2 requires the ability to send IPv4 packets between neighboring routers for those routers to exchange OSPF routing information.

	For the answers that do not cause a problem for OSPF:

	- Neighboring OSPF routers must match in regards to OSPF area, IPv4 subnet, and IPv4 subnet mask.

	- Neighboring OSPF routers may use different OSPF process IDs or the same OSPF process ID, and still become neighbors.

answerChoices.Text: An ACL could be blocking router advertisements.
Two neighboring routers that connect to the same link have been configured with the same OSPF area and with the same IPv4 subnet mask.
Any physical layer problem that would prevent two neighboring routers from being able to ping each other's IPv4 addresses in the subnet that exists between the two routers.
Two neighboring routers that connect to the same link have been configured with the same OSPF process ID on the router ospf command.

questionText: Which router mode Cisco IOS command can be used to disable the OSPF process temporarily?
explanation: Both OSPF and EIGRP processes can be temporarily disabled using the shutdown command while in OSPF/EIGRP router configuration mode.

questionText: When an IP address is configured on the routerís interface, what happens in the route table?
explanation: When an IP address is configured on a routerís interface, the network is automatically put into the route table. The IP address is also added to the route table. When the route table changes, this normally tells the routing protocol it should perform an update.

answerChoices.Text: A route entry is created for the network attached to the IP address on the interface.
A route entry is created for the IP address attached to the interface.
Dynamic routing protocols update all other routers.

questionText: In the following figure, which interface or IP address will a packet be routed to for a destination address of 192.168.4.56?
explanation: In the route table there is a static route for 192.168.4.0/24 via Serial 0/0/1. Interface Serial 0/0/0 has a route of 172.16.0.0/16 configured. The IP gateway of 192.168.4.1 does not appear in the figure. Interface Serial 0/2/0 has a route of 10.0.0.0/8 configured.

questionText: In the following figure, which interface or IP address will the packet with a destination of 198.23.34.2 be routed to?
explanation: The route will exit the Serial 0/2/0 interface, since the gateway of last resort is set to Serial 0/2/0. This statement is identified by the S* 0.0.0.0/0 entry. Interface Serial 0/1/1 has a route of 198.23.24.0/24 configured. Interface Serial 0/0/1 has a route of 192.168.1.0/24 configured. Because there is a gateway of last resort configured, any route not specifically in the route table will follow the gateway of last resort.

questionText: What is the administrative distance of OSPF?
explanation: The administrative distance (AD) of Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) is 110. The administrative distance of Internal Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP) is 90. The administrative distance of the legacy routing protocol of Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (IGRP) is 100. The administrative distance of Routing Information Protocol (RIP) is 120.

questionText: Which command will allow you to see the next advertisement interval for RIPv2?
explanation: The command show ip protocols will display the next interval when RIPv2 advertisements are sent out. The commands show ip rip database, show ip rip, and show ip interface are incorrect.

questionText: Which command will allow you to inspect RIPv2 advertisements?
explanation: The command debug ip rip will allow you to see advertisements in real time. The commands show ip protocols, debug rip, and show ip rip are incorrect.

questionText: You need to advertise the routes 192.168.1.0/24, 192.168.2.0/24, and 192.168.3.0/24. Assuming RIPv2 is configured, which configuration will achieve this?
explanation: The three Class C networks need to be advertised separately. RIPv2 uses the default class network mask when configuring networks. The command network 192.168.0.0 is incorrect as it will not advertise the individual networks of 192.168.1.0, 192.168.2.0, and 192.168.3.0. The commands network 192.168.0.0/16 and network 192.168.0.0 0.0.255.255 are incorrect.

questionText: You have RIPv2 configured on an Internet-facing router. Which command will suppress RIPv2 advertisements on the interface link?
explanation: The command passive-interface serial 0/0 configured in the router instance will suppress updates from exiting interface Serial 0/0. The commands ip rip passive-interface, rip passive-interface, and ip rip suppress-advertisement are incorrect.

questionText: Which is a problem with using RIPv2 in a network?
explanation: RIPv2 has extremely slow convergence time. This is because the advertisement of routes is every 30 seconds. So a router 4 hops away could take 120 seconds before discovering the route. Configuration for RIPv2 is rather simple compared to other protocols, such as Open Shortest Path First (OSPF). RIPv2 uses multicasts to send the complete route table to other participating routers; RIPv1 uses broadcasts. The RIPv2 protocol supports classless networks; RIPv1 does not support classless networks.

questionText: Which technique is used to stop routing loops with RIPv2?
explanation: Split horizons are used to stop routing loops with RIPv2. Split horizons prevent a router from advertising a route to a router in which the original route was discovered. Advertisement intervals can be adjusted to allow RIPv2 to converge faster. Zoning is not a design concept for RIP; therefore, it is an invalid answer. The invalid timers can be adjusted for faster convergence as well.

questionText: Which algorithm does RIPv2 use to calculate routes?
explanation: RIPv2 uses the BellmanñFord algorithm to calculate its metrics. The Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) protocol uses the Shortest Path First (SPF) algorithm, which is also called the Dijkstra algorithm. The diffusing update algorithm (DUAL) is used by Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP).

questionText: Which command will need to be configured for support of discontinuous networks?
explanation: The command no auto-summary will stop the router process of RIPv2 from auto-summarizing network addresses. In a discontiguous network, this is problematic and should be turned off. The command network discontiguous is incorrect, regardless of which prompt it is configured in. The command no auto-summary is incorrect when configured from the global configuration prompt.

questionText: Which command configures RIPv2 on a router and advertises a network of 192.168.20.0/24?
explanation: Configuring RIPv2 begins with configuration of the router instance of RIP via the command router rip. RIPv2 is configured inside of the router instance with the command version 2. Then the network of 192.168.20.0/24 is advertised with the command network 192.168.20.0. All of the other options are incorrect.

questionText: Which routing technique is best suited for small networks in which the administrator wants control of routing?
explanation: Static routing is best suited for small networks in which there is not a lot of change. It should be chosen when administrators want absolute control over the routing process. Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) is suited for large-scale networks because of its scalability. The Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP) is also a relatively scalable dynamic routing protocol. The Routing Information Protocol (RIP) is well suited for medium-sized to smaller networks, where administrators do not want to control routing.

questionText: In the following figure, Router A will not form an adjacency with Router B. What is the problem?
explanation: Both routers have passive interfaces for OSPF. In order to fix this, the command no passive-interface serial 0/0 would need to be entered. This command would need to be configured in the OSPF router process. The routers are within the same network with a common serial line connecting the routers. The process IDs do not matter and are locally significant to the routers. The hello/dead intervals for both routers match each other.

answerChoices.Text: The routers are not in the same network.
The routers have mismatched process IDs.
The hello/dead interval is wrong for serial links.

questionText: Which command will allow you to see the networks the current router is advertising for OSPF?
explanation: The command show ip protocols will list the router ID of the current router as well as the networks that are being advertised via OSPF on the current router. The commands show ip ospf, show ip ospf database, and show ip ospf neighbors are incorrect.

questionText: A client has an IP address of 192.168.1.5/24 and a default gateway of 192.168.1.1. HSRP is in use in the network. Which type of router is the default gateway?
explanation: When Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP) is used, the default gateway the client is issued is an IP address for the virtual router. The virtual router is not a physical router, but it is mapped to a physical router via HSRP. The active router processes requests for the virtual router IP address by responding to the virtual MAC address associated with the virtual router IP address. The standby router only becomes active if the active router is no longer responding with hello packets for 10 seconds. Support routers are any routers used outside of HSRP to support routing of the network.

questionText: You have been asked to recommend a private WAN technology. All of the remote offices have varied physical connectivity paths. Which private WAN technology should you recommend?
explanation: Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) allows for varied access links such as serial leased lines, Frame Relay, Metro Ethernet, and so on. You can leverage the existing connectivity methods to form a private WAN. PPPoE and GRE tunnels are connectivity methods used on top of a WAN technology, so they are invalid answers.

questionText: You configure Router A in the following figure with a route statement to get to Network B. However, you cannot ping a host on Network B. What is the problem?
explanation: Your packets are most likely making it to the destination host. However, there is no route back to your host on the other networkís router. You must enter a network route on Router B to get to Network A. You would not have been able to configure a route if the ip routing command was needed. The hosts on Network A and Network B are most likely not the problem.

answerChoices.Text: You must issue the ip routing command.
The host on Network B is misconfigured.
The host on Network A is misconfigured.
You must enter a network route on Router B for Network A.

questionText: A router has three routes to the same network: one route from RIP with a metric of 4, another from OSPF with a metric of 3053092, and another from EIGRP with a metric of 4039043. Which of the three routes will be used for the routing decision?
explanation: Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP) has the lowest administrative distance (AD) of the three protocols. Therefore, regardless of the metric, the lowest AD will always be chosen. All of the other options are incorrect.

questionText: Why can a route have a destination of an interface rather than an IP address?
explanation: Serial interfaces are point-to-point connections. Any traffic directed down the interface will automatically appear on the adjacent router. Routers will not process traffic normally unless Proxy ARP is configured for the interface. All of the other options are incorrect.

answerChoices.Text: The router on the other side of an interface routes all traffic discovered.
Routing tables cause the destination address to change.

questionText: Which command will configure a static route with an administrative distance higher than RIP?
explanation: The administrative distance (AD) can be added to the end of the route statement. Since RIP has an administrative distance of 120, 130 will be chosen if the RIP route is not present. The commands ip route 192.168.2.0 255.255.255.0 192.168.4.1 110, ip route 110 192.168.2.0 255.255.255.0 192.168.4.1, and ip route 130 192.168.2.0 255.255.255.0 192.168.4.1 are incorrect.

questionText: What is the purpose of the RIPv2 holddown timer?
explanation: The holddown timerís job is to allow the network to stabilize after a route had become unreachable via an update. This limits the potential problems related to a flapping port and allows RIPv2 to converge route updates in the entire network. The default holddown timer is set to 180 seconds. The flush timer defines the time between when the route becomes invalid and it is flushed or deleted from the route table. The default flush timer is set to 240 seconds. The invalid timer defines when a route is declared invalid. The default invalid timer is set to 180 seconds. The update timer is the timer that defines how often multicasts are sent with the complete route table. When the update is multicast to all listening neighbors, the route table will be populated with the new entries. The default update timer is set to 30 seconds.

answerChoices.Text: Holddown timers allow for time between when a route becomes invalid and it is flushed from the route table.
Holddown timers allow for time between when a route has become unreachable and when it can be updated again.
Holddown timers define the time when a route becomes invalid.
Holddown timers define the time when a valid route is present in the route table.

questionText: You are configuring RIP for a network and you need to advertise the network. Which command will advertise the route for 203.244.234.0/24?
explanation: The command network 203.244.234.0 will advertise the 203.244.234.0 network. When youíre configuring RIP, only the network address needs to be configured with the network command. The commands network 203.244.234.0 255.255.255.0, network 203.244.234.0 0.0.0.255, and network 203.244.234.0/24 are incorrect.

questionText: In the following figure, what type of routing is being used?
explanation: In the figure, packets are being sent to the router via a trunk link. A setup where the packets for VLANs are sent to a router for routing between VLANs is called router on a stick (ROAS) routing. Default routing, also known as stub routing, is normally used on stub networks, where all networks are available through the gateway of last resort. Switched virtual interface (SVI) routing is performed on layer 3 switches. A virtual interface is created that will have an IP address and routing capabilities.

questionText: Which command must be enabled on a switch to enable routing between switched virtual interfaces for VLAN routing?
explanation: When you want to turn on the layer 3 functionality of a switch, you must configure the command ip routing in global configuration. This is required when you want to create Switched Virtual Interfaces (SVIs) for VLANs and want to route on the switch between the VLANs. This method of routing is much more efficient, since the traffic is routed in the ASICs on the switch. The commands ip route svi, feature svi routing, and svi routing are incorrect.

questionText: In the following figure, Router A will not form an adjacency with Router B. What is the problem?
explanation: Both routers have passive interfaces for OSPF. In order to fix this, the command no passive-interface serial 0/0 would need to be entered. This command would need to be configured in the OSPF router process. The routers are within the same network with a common serial line connecting the routers. The process IDs do not matter and are locally significant to the routers. The hello/dead intervals for both routers match each other.

answerChoices.Text: All routers in the same area have the same neighbor table.
All routers in the same area have the same hello/dead timers.
All routers in the same area have the same topology table.
All routers in the same area have the same process IDs.

questionText: Which command will allow you to see the networks the current router is advertising for OSPF?
explanation: The command show ip protocols will list the router ID of the current router as well as the networks that are being advertised via OSPF on the current router. The commands show ip ospf, show ip ospf database, and show ip ospf neighbors are incorrect.

questionText: A client has an IP address of 192.168.1.5/24 and a default gateway of 192.168.1.1. HSRP is in use in the network. Which type of router is the default gateway?
explanation: When Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP) is used, the default gateway the client is issued is an IP address for the virtual router. The virtual router is not a physical router, but it is mapped to a physical router via HSRP. The active router processes requests for the virtual router IP address by responding to the virtual MAC address associated with the virtual router IP address. The standby router only becomes active if the active router is no longer responding with hello packets for 10 seconds. Support routers are any routers used outside of HSRP to support routing of the network.

questionText: You have been asked to recommend a private WAN technology. All of the remote offices have varied physical connectivity paths. Which private WAN technology should you recommend?
explanation: ACLs are a major consideration since they are neither TCP nor UDP; they are a layer 3 protocol of their own. The ACL required for the tunnel creation is permit gre {source} {destination}, which would be for a named access list. The tunnel interface number is only locally significant to the router. The adjoining router will never know the tunnel interface number. Speed of the tunnel is not a consideration that can restrict tunnel creation. Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) is expressly used to reduce the number of hops between the source and destination. When employed, it allows the remote network to look like it is one hop away, so the number of hops between the source and destination is not a consideration that can restrict tunnel creation.

answerChoices.Text: Number of hops between the source and destination

questionText: Which answers list a feature of GLBP that is not true about VRRPv3 or HSRPv2?
explanation:
The question asks for answers that are true of GLBP but false of VRRPv3 or HSRPv2. The one correct answer notes a feature unique to GLBP among the three: The routers in the same group use unique MAC addresses.

Three incorrect answers list factual statements about GLBP that are also true about HSRP. The facts in those three answers include:


	Cisco proprietary
	Uses multicast address 224.0.0.102
	Requires the VIP to be different than any router’s interface address.


The other two incorrect answers list statements false about GLBP:


	GLBP does not support active/standby balancing but instead supports active/active.
	GLBP does not use MAC addresses beginning with 0000.0c, instead using addresses that begin 0007:b40.

answerChoices.Text: Uses a unique virtual MAC address per router in the same group
Routers must use different interface IP addresses as compared to the FHRP VIP
Supports active/standby load balancing within one group
Uses a virtual MAC address that begins 0000.0c

questionText: How many active routers can be forwarding at the same time with a single HSRP group?
explanation: HSRP works in an active/standby configuration where only a single router is forwarding at the same time within the same HSRP group.

questionText: There are two Layer 3 switches acting as core routers called SW1 and SW2. SW1 and SW2 have the IP addresses 192.168.1.1 and 192.168.1.2 on VLAN 10, respectively. If host 1 has a configured default gateway of 192.168.1.1 and SW1 were to have a failure that brings the device offline, what protocol should be implemented to mitigate this failure scenario?
explanation:
In a design situation like this, where VLANs are being spanned between multiple Layer 3 switches that have corresponding SVIs, you would want to implement a First Hop Redundancy Protocol, such as Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP). There is a specific failure situation if you do not implement a FHRP. With host 1 having a configured default gateway of SW1, and SW1 having a failure situation that brings the device offline, host 1 has essentially lost all connectivity outside the local area network (VLAN). If you were to implement a FHRP like HSRP, this situation would be mitigated because the default gateway address would be a virtual IP address and MAC address that is shared between both SW1 and SW2.

	STP prevents switching loops and should be used while also using any FHRP solution, with STP design considered with FHRP design. For example, the root bridge and secondary root bridge placements should be on SW1 and SW2 in the question to match the FHRP active and standby roles, respectively. With that said, STP is not the protocol that can resolve the issue with a default gateway going offline.

	Running an IGP is important but the issue at hand is more of a default gateway redundancy situation.

	BGP is not pertinent to this question.

questionText: In the figure, layer 3 switches D1 and D2 use HSRP for subnet 172.16.1.0/24 in the LAN. The figure summarizes the HSRPv2 settings on D1 and D2. D1 and D2 do not use interface tracking. In sequence, D1 boots up and holds an HSRP election. One month later, the staff powers on D2. Both correctly configure HSRP to use the same group with the same VIP of 172.16.1.9.  Which answers accurately describe the results of this HSRP configuration under the conditions described in the question? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
Two answers discuss what happens during the first month of operation when only D1 works. HSRP, and all the FHRPs, work even a router realizes no other routers are participating in the group. D1 holds an HSRP election, finds no competition, wins, and becomes the HSRP active router.

For the other two related answers, you need to recall these facts about HSRP:


	It defaults to a priority value of 100.
	Higher priority wins the election.
	The preemption feature defaults to disabled.
	The per-device preemption setting defines that device’s ability to preempt (or not.) 


For the two answers that describe what happens after D2 powers up, note that neither layer 3 switch enables preemption. The question describes a classic case with a router joining the group after another router has been elected HSRP active (D1 in this case.) With preemption disabled, D2 does not attempt to take over the active role, even with a higher (better) HSRP priority.

answerChoices.Text: During the first month of operation, D1 becomes HSRP active and acts as VIP 172.16.1.9.
During the first month of operation, D1 rejects becoming HSRP active because no other routers exist in the subnet, so it does not act as VIP 172.16.1.9.
When D2 powers up, D2 becomes the HSRP active router.
When D2 powers up, D1 remains the HSRP active router.

questionText: An FHRP design scenario requires an active/standby solution that can load balance traffic per VLAN based. Which FHRP solution should be chosen?
explanation:
There are only two FHRP protocols listed, HSRP and GLBP. HSRP is an active/standby protocol while GLBP is an active/active protocol. In addition, HSRP load balances traffic per VLAN (subnet) while GLBP load balances traffic per host or end client.

	STP is used to mitigate switching loops and when utilizing FHRP solutions, STP should be designed at the same time. For example, root bridge and secondary root bridge placements should be on SW1 and SW2 in the question. With that said, STP is not the protocol that can resolve the issue with a default gateway going offline.

	SVIs are the default gateways for the VLANs in question.

questionText: The three routers all join one HSRP group for each of the three subnets in the figure. The virtual IP address the devices in VLAN 10 use is 10.0.0.50. VLAN 10 contains more than ten hosts, with PC1, PC2, and PC3 as examples. How many of the routers will be actively forwarding traffic for the VLAN 10 users?
explanation:
In HSRP, routers do not share the workload for a specific VLAN. If load balancing is wanted, a preference could be configured for each router to actively forward for a single subnet and provide standby service for the other VLANs. There is only one active forwarder per VLAN per group in HSRP.

Because the correct answer is one forwarder per VLAN/network, the other choices are not correct.

questionText: Which answers list a feature of VRRPv3 that is not true about either HSRPv2 or GLBP? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
The question stem asks for answers true of VRRPv3 but also not true of HSRPv2 or GLBP. Of the listed answers, the two correct answers are true of VRRPv3 and untrue of the others. Of the incorrect answers:

•    Both HSRPv2 and GLBP, but not VRRPv3, use multicast address 224.0.0.102.
•    GLBP, but not others, uses virtual MAC addresses beginning with 0007.b4.
•    Both HSRPv2 and VRRPv3 support active/standby load balancing within one group.
•    VRRPv3  does not use a unique virtual MAC per router, instead sharing one virtual MAC address among all the routers in the group.

answerChoices.Text: Uses a unique virtual MAC address per router in the same group
The VIP may be identical to one of the group’s router interface IP addresses
Supports active/standby load balancing within one group
Uses a virtual MAC address that begins 0007.b4

questionText: Layer 3 switches D1 and D2 use GLBP with group number 20 and VIP 172.16.1.99. GLBP identifies layer three switch D1 as router 01 and D2 as router 02. All links in the figure work. The PCs use 172.16.1.99 as their default router. Which statement best describes how GLBP achieves load balancing? (Choose two answers.)
explanation:
GLBP uses active/active load balancing within one GLBP group. To do so, one router or multilayer switch acts as the active virtual gateway (AVG), performing some important asks for the group. However, all routers (or multilayer switches) act as active virtual forwarders (AVFs), actively forwarding packets. (Those facts show the reasons for one correct and one incorrect answer.)

To allow multiple concurrent AVFs, each AVF uses a unique virtual MAC address. Over time, when different hosts ARP looking for the MAC address associated with the GLBP VIP, the AVG alternates replies, one with the virtual MAC of one of the AVFs, and the next for another AVF. By alternating the ARP responses, a subset of the hosts in the subnet refers to each AVF’s virtual MAC. So, a single host always sends packets to one AVF, but collectively the hosts send some packets to one AVF and some to the other.
comments: Formerly 200301-WO-v2-1-app-006 from the 2023 Exam Updates question batch.

answerChoices.Text: Both multilayer switches act as an AVF to provide active/active load balancing.
Both multilayer switches act as an AVG to provide active/active load balancing.
Both multilayer implement the same virtual MAC address
Each multilayer switch implements a unique virtual MAC address

questionText: Which answers list a feature of HSRPv2 that is not true about VRRPv3 or GLBP?
explanation:
The question asks for answers true of HSRPv2 but also not true of VRRPv3 or GLBP. Of the listed answers, the one correct answer is the only one both true of HSRPv2 and untrue of the others. Of the incorrect answers:

•    Both HSRPv2 and GLBP are Cisco proprietary, use multicast address 224.0.0.102, and require the VIP to be different than any router’s interface address.
•    Both HSRPv2 and VRRPv3 support active/standby load balancing within one group.
•    HSRPv2 does not use a unique virtual MAC per router.

answerChoices.Text: Uses a unique virtual MAC address per router in the same group
The VIP cannot be the same as any of the routers’ interface IP addresses in the group
Supports active/standby load balancing within one group
Uses a virtual MAC address that begins 0000.0c

questionText: Refer to the exhibit. A network administrator is connecting a new host to the Registrar LAN. The host needs to communicate with remote networks. What IP address would be configured as the default gateway on the new host?
explanation: The default gateway for a host on a LAN is the IP address of the router interface that connects to that specific LAN. In the provided configuration, the `interface gi0/1` is described as 'Connects to the Registrar LAN' and has the IP address `192.168.235.234`. Therefore, this IP address would be the default gateway for hosts on the Registrar LAN.

questionText: What routing table entry has a next hop address associated with a destination network?
explanation: Routing table entries for remote routes will have a next hop IP address. The next hop IP address is the address of the router interface of the next device to be used to reach the destination network. Directly-connected and local routes have no next hop, because they do not require going through another router to be reached.

questionText: If the default gateway is configured incorrectly on the host, what is the impact on communications?
explanation: A default gateway is only required to communicate with devices on another network. The absence of a default gateway does not affect connectivity between devices on the same local network.

answerChoices.Text: There is no impact on communications.
The host is unable to communicate on the local network.
The host can communicate with other hosts on the local network, but is unable to communicate with hosts on remote networks.
The host can communicate with other hosts on remote networks, but is unable to communicate with hosts on the local network.

questionText: Refer to the diagram; which Cisco IOS command would be configured on R1’s Gi0/0.200 interface so that it handles all traffic marked for VLAN 200?
explanation: The encapsulation dot1q vlan command is used to assign a specific router subinterface to a trunk VLAN. In this case the encapsulation dot1q 200 command would allow R1’s Gi0/0.200 to handle all traffic marked with VLAN 200.

questionText: In the internetwork shown in the diagram, R1 is the central site router, and R2 is a typical remote office router. The network manager dictates that the remote routers should all use a default route to forward packets back to the central site, while the central site router should use a static route to forward packets to each remote office's LAN subnet. As soon as the network manager has correctly implemented this design, you connect to R1 and R2 using Telnet and issue the show ip route command on each router. Which of the following answers list output you should see in the routers?
explanation:
On R1: As a central site router, R1 needs a route for R2's specific LAN subnet of 172.17.6.64/26, which can be derived from the information in the diagram. Of the two answers for router R1, only one lists 172.17.6.64, with a correct next hop of R2's serial IP address 172.16.1.2.

	On R2: The default route is needed on R2, a branch office router, so the show ip route command should list a destination/mask of 0.0.0.0/0. Of the two incorrect answers for router R2, one answer refers to 172.16.1.2 (R2's IP address) as a next-hop address, but it should refer to R1's IP address. The other incorrect answer lists a route to subnet 10.55.44.0, which is not a default route, but the question stated that the remote router must use a default route. So, the option that lists 0.0.0.0/0 as the destination, with an outgoing interface (on R2) of S0/0/0, is the expected route on R2.
comments:
12/20 - ok as-is, "The figure shows the IP address and mask for all the router interfaces, including R2’s Fa0/0 interface address 172.17.6.66/26. The static route on R1 mentioned in the question should be for the subnet connected to that interface. To know that number, which is the number that ends in .64, you’d apply subnetting path to the address/mask to find the subnet id/mask. In this case, the subnet ID is 172.17.6.64."

12/13 - query to Au

4/9 - query to Au, CD-I1-4-08-002-1

questionText: After configuring an IP address on and enabling a router interface, which route(s) will be automatically added to the routerís routing table?
explanation: When an IP address is configured on an active router interface, two types of routes are automatically added to the routerís routing table: a connected route (C) and a local route (L). The connected route indicates the network directly connected to the router, and the local route indicates the exact IP address of the routerís interface with a /32 prefix length.

questionText: Which type of route represents the exact IP address of a routerís interface with a /32 prefix length?
explanation: A local (L) route in the routing table represents the exact IP address of a routerís interface with a /32 prefix length. A local route is automatically created by the router for each of its active interfaces.

questionText: If a packetís destination IP address doesnít match any routes in the routing table, what action will the router take on the packet?
explanation: If a packetís destination IP address does not match any entries in the routerís routing table, the router doesnít know how to forward the packet. As a result, the router will drop the packet. Routers donít flood messages like switches.

answerChoices.Text: It will broadcast the packet out of all interfaces.
It will use ARP to identify the next hop.
It will receive the packet for itself.

questionText: Which of the following is a host route?
explanation: A host route is a route to a single IP address, represented by a /32 prefix length. The route to 8.8.8.8/32 is a host route as it specifies a single IP address: 8.8.8.8.

questionText: Which of the following commands configures a recursive static route?
explanation: A recursive static route specifies the next-hop IP address, not the exit interface. It is ìrecursiveî because it requires an additional routing table lookup: after the router has determined the next-hop IP address, it must perform an additional lookup to determine which interface the next hop is connected to.

questionText: Which route in its routing table will a router select to forward a packet?
explanation: When forwarding a packet, a router will choose the most specific matching route in its routing table; this is the matching route with the longest prefix length.

answerChoices.Text: The route with the longest prefix length
The route with the shortest prefix length
The route that matches the most IP addresses

questionText: Which of the following commands configures a default route?
explanation: A default route is a route to 0.0.0.0/0óa route that matches all possible IP addresses. When the router has a default route in its routing table, it will use the route to forward packets that donít match any more specific routes.

questionText: Which of the following static routes relies on proxy ARP?
explanation: This route relies on proxy ARP because it specifies only the exit interface; itís a directly connected static route. This makes the router behave as if it were directly connected to the destination, and it will therefore send an ARP request directly to the destination IP address (instead of to the next-hop routerís IP address). This will only work if the next-hop router has proxy ARP enabled and can reply to the ARP request.

questionText: In a ROAS configuration, which command tells the router which VLAN to tag frames with?
explanation: In a router-on-a-stick (ROAS) configuration, the command encapsulation dot1q vlan-id is used in subinterface configuration mode to specify the VLAN ID for tagging frames. The VLAN ID doesnít have to match the subinterface ID (i.e. GigabitEthernet0/1.10), but itís best to match them for simplicityís sake.

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a requirement for an SVI to be in an up/up state?
explanation: For a switch virtual interface (SVI) to be in an up/up state, the switch must have either an access port associated with the VLAN or a trunk port that allows the VLAN; it is not necessary to have both.

answerChoices.Text: The VLAN associated with the SVI must exist on the switch.
The switch must have both an access port associated with the VLAN and a trunk port that allows the VLAN.

questionText: When connecting two switches with a Layer-3 EtherChannel, where should each switchís IP address be configured?
explanation: In a Layer-3 EtherChannel, IP addressing is configured on the port-channel interface rather than on the individual member ports. This setup allows the EtherChannel to function as a single logical interface at Layer 3.

answerChoices.Text: On both the port-channel interface and the member ports

questionText: Which type of dynamic routing protocol is used to exchange routing information within an AS?
explanation: Interior gateway protocols (IGPs) are used to exchange routing information within an autonomous system (AS). Examples include OSPF, EIGRP, RIP, and IS-IS. This is in contrast to exterior gateway protocols (EGPs) like BGP, which are used to exchange routing information between ASs.

questionText: Which of the following dynamic routing protocols use a link-state algorithm? (select two)
explanation: IS-IS and OSPF are both link-state routing protocols. They maintain a complete map of the network topology to make routing decisions.

questionText: Which type of routing protocol is also known as ìrouting by rumorî?
explanation: Distance-vector routing protocols are often referred to as ìrouting by rumorî because the router doesnít build a complete map of the network; it only knows what its neighbors tell it.

questionText: When multiple routes to the same destination network are learned via the same routing protocol, which parameter is used to select which route(s) will enter the routing table?
explanation: When a router learns multiple routes to the same destination from the same routing protocol, the route with the lowest metric is selected for the routing table.

questionText: When multiple routes to the same destination network are learned via different routing protocols, which parameter is used to select which route(s) will enter the routing table?
explanation: When routes to the same destination are learned via different routing protocols, the administrative distance (AD) is used to determine the preferred route. The route with the lowest AD is selected. Each routing protocol calculates route metric values differently, so they canít be directly compared.

questionText: Which of the following accurately represent IOS default AD values? (select two)
explanation: Here are some default AD values in Cisco IOS: connected = 0, static = 1, External BGP (EBGP) = 20, EIGRP = 90, OSPF = 110, IS-IS = 115, RIP = 120, Internal BGP (IBGP) = 200, unusable = 255.

questionText: If a Cisco router learns multiple routes to the same destination via the same routing protocol, and all routes have the same metric, what is the maximum number of routes to that destination that the router will insert into its routing table by default?
explanation: By default, Cisco routers can load-balance across up to four equal-cost paths; this is called equal-cost multi-path (ECMP) routing. If multiple routes to the same destination have the same metric, up to four of them can be inserted into the routing table for load balancing.

questionText: What kind of static route acts as a backup for another route, only entering the routing table if the more preferred route is removed from the routing table?
explanation: A floating static route is a static route with a higher AD than the primary route. It acts as a backup and is used only if the primary route is unavailable.

questionText: A router learns the following routes via manual configuration and dynamic routing protocols. Which route(s) will it insert into its routing table? (select all that apply)
explanation: The router has learned routes to three different destination networks: 10.0.0.0/8, 10.0.0.0/16, and 10.0.0.0/24. It has only learned one route to each of 10.0.0.0/8 and 10.0.0.0/24, so it will insert both routes as isóno need to compare them with other routes. Then, the router will select which route to 10.0.0.0/16 to insert. The static route has a lower AD (1) than the OSPF route (110), so it will insert the static route into its routing table. Note that ìselect all that applyî questions will not appear on the CCNA exam; if you need to select multiple answers, it will state exactly how many you need to select (select two, select three, etc).

questionText: A router learns the following routes via manual configuration and dynamic routing protocols. Which route(s) will it insert into its routing table? (select all that apply)
explanation: The router has learned four different routes to a single destination network: 192.168.1.0/24. So it will only insert one route into its routing table (unless ECMP comes into play). The static route has been configured with a non-default AD (89). However, its AD is still lower than that of the EIGRP route (90), so the router will insert the static route into its routing table. When configuring a floating static route, make sure to configure it so that its AD is sufficiently high to make it less preferred than other routes.

questionText: A router receives a packet destined for 192.0.2.29. It has the following four routes in its routing table. Which route will it select to forward the packet?
explanation: When selecting which route should be used to forward a particular packet, the router only considers one thing: the most specific matching route. AD and metric are not considered. In this case, only the route to 192.0.2.0/27 (option A) matches the packetís destination IP address, so the router will forward the packet according to that routeís instructions.

questionText: A router receives a packet destined for 10.23.107.126. It has the following four routes in its routing table. Which route will it select to forward the packet?
explanation: In this case, three routes match the packetís destination IP address: the route to 10.23.107.0/25 (A), the route to 10.23.107.96/27 (C), and the route to 10.23.107.112/28 (D). The route to 10.23.107.112/28 has the longest prefix length, so it is the most specific matching route; the router will forward the packet according to that routeís instructions.

questionText: R1ís G0/1 interface has the IP address 192.168.209.101/30. Which of the following network commands would activate OSPF on the interface? (select all that apply)
explanation: The OSPF network command is quite flexible; as long as the appropriate bits match between the interfaceís IP address and the address in the network command (those indicated by a ì0î bit in the wildcard mask), OSPF will be activated on the interface. In this case, all three network statements match the appropriate bits in the interfaceís IP address, so all three commands would activate OSPF on the interface.

questionText: R1 is part of an OSPF network, and all of its OSPF-enabled interfaces are in area 1. Furthermore, it connects to the Internet and advertises a default route to other OSPF routers. What OSPF router types apply to R1? (select all that apply).
explanation: R1 is an internal router because all of its OSPF-enabled interfaces are in a single area (area 1). Itís also an autonomous system boundary router (ASBR) because it connects to an external network (the Internet) and advertises a default route to other OSPF routers. It is not an area border router (ABR) because it does not connect to multiple OSPF areas, nor is it a backbone router because itís not in area 0.

questionText: What command should you configure on a router to ensure that all GigabitEthernet interfaces have an OSPF cost of 10?
explanation: OSPFís automatic cost calculation uses the formula ìreference bandwidth/interface bandwidthî. The auto-cost reference-bandwidth command is configured in Mbps, so to make a 1 Gbps (1000 Mbps) interface have a cost of 10, the reference bandwidth should be 10000 Mbps (10000/1000 = 10).

questionText: What is the effect of the passive-interface command on an OSPF-activated interface?
explanation: The passive-interface command in OSPF stops the router from sending OSPF hello packets out of the interface, preventing OSPF neighbor relationships from forming on that interface. However, the network connected to the interface will still be advertised to other OSPF routers.

answerChoices.Text: The router will attempt to form OSPF neighbor relationships on the interface, but wonít send hello messages out of the interface.
The router will advertise the interfaceís network to other OSPF routers, but wonít send hello messages out of the interface.
The router will send hello messages out of the interface, but wonít advertise the interfaceís network to other OSPF routers.
The router will send hello messages out of the interface, but wonít attempt to form OSPF neighbor relationships on the interface.

questionText: Which of the following represents the order of priority when a router decides its OSPF RID?
explanation: The OSPF Router ID (RID) is determined in this order of priority: first, a manually configured router ID; second, the highest IP address on any active loopback interface; third, the highest IP address on any active physical interface.

answerChoices.Text: 1) Manual configuration, 2) Highest IP address on a loopback interface, 3) Highest IP address on a physical interface
1) Manual configuration, 2) Lowest IP address on a loopback interface, 3) Lowest IP address on a physical interface
1) Manual configuration, 2) Highest IP address on a physical interface, 3) Highest IP address on a loopback interface
1) Manual configuration, 2) Lowest IP address on a physical interface, 3) Lowest IP address on a loopback interface

questionText: R1 has multiple OSPF neighbor relationships. R1ís OSPF RID is 192.168.1.1, which was inherited from a physical interfaceís IP address. You then configure the IP address 10.0.0.2 on a loopback interface and configure router-id 1.1.1.1 in router config mode for the OSPF process. What is R1ís RID after you issue the router-id 1.1.1.1 command?
explanation: Once a router has determined its RID and established an OSPF neighbor relationship with another router, the only way to change the RID is to manually configure it with the router-id rid command and then reset the OSPF process with clear ip ospf process. However, the scenario does not indicate that you reset the OSPF process, so R1ís RID remains 192.168.1.1.

questionText: Which of the following commands activates OSPF on an interface without using the network command?
explanation: You can use the ip ospf process-id area area-id in interface config mode to activate OSPF on the interface. This is generally preferred over the network command due to its simplicity.

questionText: Four routers connected to a segment with the OSPF broadcast network type have the default OSPF priority. R4 is the DR and R3 is the BDR. You configure ip ospf priority 100 on R2ís interface connected to the segment and reset OSPF on R4 with clear ip ospf process. Which of the following statements is true after you reset R4ís OSPF process?
explanation: When the OSPF process of R4 (the DR) is reset, R3 (the BDR) immediately takes over its role as the DR, even though R2ís interface now has the highest priority (100, whereas others have the default of 1). Then, an election is held to determine the new BDR; R2 wins this due to its higher priority and becomes the BDR.

answerChoices.Text: R2 is the DR and R3 is the BDR.
R3 is the DR and R2 is the BDR.
R2 is the DR and R4 is the BDR.
R3 is the DR and R4 is the BDR

questionText: Which of the following commands can be used to prevent routers from electing a DR/BDR?
explanation: Whereas OSPF neighbors using the broadcast network type hold DR/BDR elections, those using the point-to-point network type do not. The default network type of Ethernet interfaces is broadcast, but you can use ip ospf network point-to-point to configure the point-to-point network type.

questionText: Which of the following are requirements for two routers to become OSPF neighbors? (select two)
explanation: For two routers to become OSPF neighbors, their RIDs must be unique, and their hello and dead timers must match. The other two options are incorrect because the area numbers must match (not be unique) and the RIDs must be unique (not match).

answerChoices.Text: Hello and dead timers must match.

questionText: Which of the following represents the order of priority when routers elect a DR/BDR?
explanation: The router with the highest interface priority is elected as the DR of an OSPF broadcast network. If there is a tie, the router with the highest RID becomes the DR. Then, an election using identical rules is held to determine the BDR.

questionText: Which of the following statements about the virtual IP and virtual MAC used by HSRP are true?
explanation: The Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP) active and standby routers share a virtual IP address (VIP) and virtual MAC address. This allows for a seamless failover from the active router to the standby router; end hosts donít have to update their default gateway IP address or ARP table when a failover occurs.

answerChoices.Text: The active and standby routers share a VIP, but each uses a different virtual MAC address.
The active and standby routers each use a different VIP, but share a virtual MAC address.
The active and standby routers share a VIP and virtual MAC address.
The active and standby router each use different VIPs and virtual MAC addresses.

questionText: During HSRP failover, what is the purpose of the new active router sending GARP messages?
explanation: As the previous explanation mentioned, end hosts donít have to update their default gateway IP address or ARP table when a failover from active to standby occurs. Instead, the gratuitous ARP (GARP) messages sent by the new active router serve to make switches update their MAC address tables. This allows them to correctly forward frames to the new active router.
